Salazar had recently given birth to premature twins and was advised by doctors to recover at home during the scheduled court date. Despite the medical circumstances, the family was detained and deported without access to basic necessities like coats in cold weather. Her husband, Federico Arellano, a U.S. citizen, has fought to reunite with his family after the deportation to Reynosa, Mexico, where they had no contacts or resources.

title: Nearly 40 Student Visas Revoked Over Minor Infractions Amid Crackdown
summary: In early April 2025, U.S. immigration authorities revoked the visas of nearly 40 international students across major universities, often citing minor or dismissed legal infractions such as traffic violations. The revocations followed comments by Secretary of State Marco Rubio boasting about intensified scrutiny of foreign students. Universities affected include UC Berkeley, UCLA, Stanford, and Ohio State. Immigration attorneys and advocacy groups raised alarms about due process violations, as many students were not given prior notice or clear explanations before their visas were revoked.

title: U.S. Citizen with Intellectual Disabilities Wrongfully Detained by Border Patrol
summary: On April 8, 2025, 19-year-old U.S. citizen Jose Hermosillo was arrested by Customs and Border Protection agents in Tucson, Arizona, and briefly prosecuted for illegal entry. Despite providing documentation of his citizenship, Hermosillo — who suffers from intellectual disabilities, cannot read or write, and has difficulty speaking — was detained for 10 days. Officials justified the arrest based on a sworn statement Hermosillo signed under questioning, although family members and advocates argue he could not have understood the form. The incident drew national attention to the treatment of disabled individuals in immigration enforcement.

title: Two U.S. Citizen Children, Ages 4 and 7, Deported to Honduras
summary: On April 25, 2025, two U.S. citizen children, ages 4 and 7, were deported to Honduras alongside their undocumented mother, following detention at a routine ICE check-in in Louisiana. According to their lawyer, the mother was given no meaningful choice to leave her children in the United States. The 4-year-old boy suffers from late-stage cancer and was deprived of critical medications and access to doctors while in ICE custody. The deportation raised alarms about due process violations and the Trump administration’s handling of U.S. citizen minors caught up in mass immigration enforcement sweeps.

title: Two-Year-Old U.S. Citizen Detained and Scheduled for Deportation
summary: In late April 2025, a two-year-old U.S. citizen, identified in court records as V.M.L., was detained with her mother and 11-year-old sibling during a routine immigration check-in at the New Orleans ICE office. Despite documentation showing her birth in New Orleans in 2023, the child was processed for deportation. Lawyers argued that the deportation occurred without adequate opportunity for the child's father, a U.S. citizen, to assert custody rights. A federal judge expressed serious concerns about the violation of the child's due process rights, and immigration advocates raised alarms about broader citizenship rights violations.

title: German Teenagers Strip-Searched and Deported for Incomplete Travel Plans
summary: In March 2025, two German teenagers, Charlotte Pohl (19) and Maria Lepere (18), were detained by U.S. Customs and Border Protection after arriving in Honolulu, Hawaii, without proof of accommodations for their entire stay. The young women reported being interrogated for hours, strip-searched, placed in prison uniforms, and held in cells with criminal detainees before being deported. Immigration authorities cited visa violations for the deportation, but civil liberties advocates condemned the treatment as unnecessarily harsh for travelers with no criminal background.

title: Members of Congress Condemn Conditions at Louisiana Detention Facilities
summary: In April 2025, members of Louisiana's congressional delegation publicly condemned the conditions at state detention facilities where immigrants, including international students like Rümeysa Öztürk, were being held. After visiting the facilities and meeting with detainees, lawmakers described inhumane conditions, lack of due process, and raised concerns about the treatment of legally present students. The events highlighted broader criticisms of the Trump administration's immigration and detention policies targeting international students.

title: Rookie Teacher Deported Shortly After Beginning Career in Florida
summary: Wualner Sauceda, a 24-year-old science teacher at Palm Springs Middle School in Hialeah, Florida, was detained in early January 2025 and deported to Honduras on February 6. Sauceda had no known criminal history and had just begun his teaching career when he was arrested. His deportation sparked outrage among students, parents, and immigration advocates who questioned the administration's sweeping enforcement actions against community members with strong ties to the United States.

title: Maryland Resident Alexi Canas Detained Over Minor Traffic Violation
summary: On March 10, 2025, Alexi Canas, a Maryland resident with no criminal record, was detained after appearing in court to address a suspended license charge. Canas was flagged through the Frederick County Sheriff's Office 287(g) program, which allows local law enforcement to collaborate with ICE. His detention raised alarms about the targeting of individuals over minor infractions and the expansion of immigration enforcement into local judicial processes.

title: Executive Branch Club Opening in Georgetown
summary: A new invitation-only club called 'Executive Branch' opened in Georgetown, Washington D.C., backed by Donald Trump Jr. and megadonor Omeed Malik. According to Politico reporter Dasha Burns, membership costs over $500,000 and is designed to allow top business executives to have private conversations with Trump advisors and cabinet members. The club reportedly already has a waiting list.

title: Record-Breaking Trump Inauguration Fundraising
summary: Trump's 2025 inauguration raised an unprecedented $239 million, which combined with the $107 million from his 2017 inauguration totals $346 million—more than all other inaugural committees since 1973 combined. The single largest donor was Pilgrim's Pride at $5 million. The funds not spent on inauguration festivities can be directed toward other Trump projects with minimal oversight.

title: USDA Withdraws Biden-Era Salmonella Safety Rule
summary: The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) withdrew a Biden-era rule that would have required poultry companies to keep salmonella bacteria below certain levels. The CDC had previously stated that salmonella causes 1.35 million infections and 420 deaths annually, with the rule estimated to reduce salmonella illnesses by 25%. Pilgrim's Pride, which donated $5 million to Trump's inaugural committee, has executives on the board of the National Chicken Council that praised the withdrawal.

title: Musk's DOGE Team Working on Secret FAA 'Project Lift'
summary: Elon Musk's 'Department of Government Efficiency' (DOGE) staffers are reportedly working on a multimillion-dollar communications project at the Federal Aviation Administration called 'Project Lift.' The project appears to involve inserting Musk's Starlink into a $2.4 billion contract currently held by Verizon. FAA employees have been made to sign nondisclosure agreements, limiting public information about this taxpayer-funded project.

title: Trump Sons Seek Early Stock Sale from AI Company Advisory Roles
summary: Shortly after Trump announced the administration's push to loosen regulations for AI, his sons Donald Jr. and Eric joined the advisory board of AI company Dominari Holdings, Inc., receiving 750,000 shares each despite having no official duties. The Trumps also invested in Dominari's subsidiary, American Data Center, Inc. Dominari stock increased by over 1,000% after the Trump sons joined, and recent SEC filings show they're seeking permission to sell their shares worth $5.8 million each earlier than normally allowed.

title: Trump Administration Creating Controversial Government 'Lists' of Vulnerable Groups
summary: The Trump administration has initiated multiple data collection efforts targeting specific groups, including texting Barnard College faculty to ask if they're Jewish and creating a controversial 'disease registry' for people with autism. Additionally, the IRS has agreed to share confidential tax records with Immigration and Customs Enforcement to help deport an estimated 7 million undocumented immigrants, despite longstanding privacy protections. Critics warn these practices threaten privacy, evoke historical abuses of government data collection, and may discourage tax payments from undocumented immigrants who contributed an estimated $96.7 billion in taxes in 2022.

title: DOGE Was Bad. Schedule F Will Be Worse
summary: President Trump issued an executive order on April 18, 2025 resurrecting 'Schedule F,' which would convert approximately 50,000 federal government employees to 'at-will' status, making them effectively political appointees who serve at the president's pleasure. The order allows for the firing of civil servants for 'subversion of Presidential directives' and has been challenged by multiple lawsuits, including one from the National Treasury Employees Union arguing it violates Congressional intent. While acknowledging legitimate concerns about accountability in federal employment, the article argues this approach prioritizes personal loyalty over Constitutional obligations and would make government less effective.

title: Harvard University Sues Trump Administration Over Funding Freeze
summary: Harvard University filed a federal lawsuit against the Trump administration challenging a $2.3 billion funding freeze imposed after the university rejected government demands to eliminate diversity programs, ban masks at protests, and provide foreign student data. The lawsuit claimed the government's actions violated the First Amendment and other laws by using federal funding as leverage to control academic decisions. Following Harvard's legal action, more than 200 university and college presidents issued a joint statement condemning what they described as political interference in higher education.

title: Invitation-Only 'Executive Branch' Club Opens in Georgetown
summary: A new invitation-only club called 'Executive Branch' opened in Georgetown, Washington D.C., backed by Donald Trump Jr. and megadonor Omeed Malik. According to reporting, membership costs over $500,000 and is designed to allow top business executives to have private conversations with Trump advisors and cabinet members. The exclusive venue reportedly already has a waiting list, with some aspiring members offering to pay double the membership fee to skip the line, and offers unprecedented access to administration decision-makers.

title: Trump Declares Harvard Will Lose Tax-Exempt Status; University Vows to Resist
summary: President Trump announced he was 'taking away Harvard's Tax Exempt Status,' escalating the administration's confrontation with the university after it refused federal demands to modify its policies. Harvard responded that there was 'no legal basis' for the action and warned it would harm student financial aid, medical research, and innovation. Federal law prohibits the president from directing IRS tax investigations, with violations requiring reporting to an internal watchdog. The move followed Harvard's lawsuit against the administration for freezing over $2 billion in federal funds.

title: Trump Administration Asks Supreme Court to Allow DOGE Access to Social Security Data
summary: The Trump administration asked the Supreme Court to overturn a federal judge's ruling that blocked members of Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency from accessing sensitive records of the Social Security Administration. Judge Ellen Hollander of the U.S. District Court in Maryland had imposed restrictions in March after finding that scrutiny of the agency's sensitive information systems likely violated federal privacy laws. The administration argued the order 'inflicts ongoing, irreparable harm on urgent federal priorities,' while the judge had described DOGE's efforts as a 'fishing expedition' that intruded into 'the personal affairs of millions of Americans.'

title: Federal Judge Rules Trump's Order Targeting Law Firm Perkins Coie Unconstitutional
summary: U.S. District Judge Beryl Howell permanently blocked the Trump administration from enforcing its executive order targeting law firm Perkins Coie, ruling it an unconstitutional effort to punish the firm for representing clients and causes the president disfavors. In a 102-page opinion, Judge Howell described the order as an 'unprecedented attack' on the independence of lawyers and found it violated the First, Fifth, and Sixth Amendments. The ruling represented the first time a court permanently blocked one of Trump's executive orders against law firms, which had threatened their ability to conduct business by suspending security clearances, barring access to federal buildings, and canceling government contracts.

title: Justice Department Under Bondi Prioritizes Loyalty to Trump, Ex-Prosecutors Warn
summary: Former federal prosecutors and legal experts warned that Attorney General Pam Bondi had transformed the Department of Justice into a politically loyal entity that prioritizes allegiance to President Trump. Since taking office, Bondi established a 'weaponization working group,' halted prosecutions of Trump allies, fired or forced out prosecutors who worked on January 6 and Trump-related cases, paused foreign bribery investigations, and publicly threatened judges. Critics characterized these actions as damaging to the rule of law, with one former prosecutor describing it as turning DOJ into Trump's 'personal law firm.'

title: Trump Administration's Tariff Policies Threaten Dollar Dominance and Global Financial Stability
summary: According to economist Kenneth Rogoff, the Trump administration's unpredictable and aggressive tariff policies have caused significant damage to global trust in the dollar's stability. In the immediate aftermath of Trump's tariff announcements, markets witnessed an unprecedented situation where the dollar's value declined while long-term interest rates increased - a sign of foreign investors selling off dollar assets. Rogoff, a former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, warns this represents a permanent shift that has already increased U.S. borrowing costs by up to half a percent, which would cost billions given America's $37 trillion debt. The administration's approach to treating dollar dominance as a burden rather than a privilege that requires careful stewardship has accelerated trends that Rogoff believes could lead to 8% or higher inflation within the next 3-4 years and significant reductions in America's financial leverage internationally.

title: Trump Administration Targets Former Cybersecurity Chief Who Debunked 2020 Election Lies
summary: Trump administration officials confirmed that Chris Krebs, former head of the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency who debunked Trump's false 2020 election claims, has lost his Global Entry travel privileges due to an unspecified federal investigation. This follows President Trump's directive on April 9 ordering the Justice Department to investigate Krebs as an act of retaliation, during which Trump also suspended Krebs' security clearance. In the original memo, Trump accused Krebs of being 'a significant bad-faith actor' who engaged in 'censorship of disfavored speech' about the 2020 election. The investigation has already forced Krebs to resign from his cybersecurity firm position to focus on his legal defense.

title: Trump Fires National Security Advisor Mike Waltz After Signal Scandal
summary: President Trump dismissed National Security Advisor Mike Waltz following a scandal involving the use of an unsecured messaging app, TeleMessage Signal, to discuss classified military operations. Waltz had inadvertently included a journalist in a group chat detailing plans for a strike on Houthi targets in Yemen. Despite the breach, Trump nominated Waltz as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, a move that has drawn criticism and is expected to face scrutiny during Senate confirmation hearings.

title: DOGE Workforce Cuts at National Park Service Reach 25%
summary: Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) has announced plans to lay off an additional 1,500 National Park Service employees, bringing total staffing cuts to approximately 5,000, or one-quarter of the agency's workforce. Internal documents suggest that the cuts target regional and national offices to minimize public visibility, prompting concerns about the impact on park operations and visitor experiences.

title: Judge Blocks Use of Alien Enemies Act to Deport Venezuelans
summary: U.S. District Judge Fernando Rodriguez Jr., appointed by President Trump, ruled that the administration's use of the 1798 Alien Enemies Act to deport Venezuelan migrants in South Texas was unlawful. The judge stated that the law requires a formal declaration of war or evidence of a military invasion, neither of which were present, thereby setting a significant legal precedent limiting executive authority in immigration enforcement.

title: ICE Raids Oklahoma Home, Detains Wrong Family of U.S. Citizens
summary: Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents raided a home in Oklahoma City, detaining a mother and her three daughters, all U.S. citizens, in the rain and seizing their personal belongings, including phones and cash. The agents later acknowledged that the family was not the intended target of the operation. The incident has sparked outrage and raised questions about oversight and accountability within federal law enforcement agencies.

title: Whistleblower Reveals DOGE Breach of Labor Board Data
summary: A whistleblower from the National Labor Relations Board disclosed that Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) gained unauthorized access to internal labor case systems, exfiltrated sensitive union and corporate data, and attempted to cover its tracks by disabling logging tools and deleting audit records. Cybersecurity experts compared the behavior to state-sponsored attacks. The breach has raised concerns about retaliation against union organizers and the risk of foreign adversaries exploiting newly exposed federal systems.

title: DOGE Constructs Master Database of Federal Records, Prompting Legal Challenge
summary: Whistleblowers and legal filings reveal that DOGE has begun aggregating sensitive personal data across federal agencies, forming a central database reportedly housed at the Department of Homeland Security. The system pulls from Social Security, IRS, and HHS records and allegedly uses AI to flag dissenters. Two court rulings have already limited DOGE’s access under the Privacy Act, though data already collected may remain in use. Critics describe the system as 'turnkey totalitarianism' and warn of chilling effects on civil liberties.

title: Judge Orders Trump Officials to Release Withheld Funds to Radio Free Europe
summary: A federal judge ordered the Trump administration to disburse $12 million in congressionally approved funds to Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty after the administration stalled payments despite earlier court rulings. The judge ruled that the delay was unlawful and violated congressional authority. The administration had attempted to use funding leverage to influence the broadcaster’s editorial independence and board appointments.

title: Behind Trump's Deal to Deport Venezuelans to El Salvador's Maximum-Security Prison
summary: The Trump administration deported over 200 Venezuelans to El Salvador's CECOT mega-prison under a secretive agreement invoking the Alien Enemies Act. Some migrants had pending asylum cases or no criminal records. Internal documents reveal President Bukele sought verification that the deportees were gang-affiliated, raising questions about the legality and due process of mass deportations. The agreement included side deals to return high-profile MS-13 leaders to El Salvador despite pending U.S. cases.

title: Judge Orders Release of Columbia Student Detained by ICE for Pro-Palestinian Speech
summary: Columbia philosophy student Mohsen Mahdawi was released from federal custody after a judge ruled his detention by ICE likely stemmed from retaliation for pro-Palestinian activism, violating First Amendment protections. Mahdawi, a U.S. permanent resident, had been detained at his naturalization interview under a provision alleging he posed a foreign policy threat. The judge called the case reminiscent of McCarthy-era excesses.

title: Trump Organization Launches Qatari Real Estate Deal with State-Owned Developer
summary: Eric Trump signed a deal with Qatari Diar, a firm owned by Qatar's sovereign wealth fund, to build a Trump-branded golf course and luxury villas in Doha. The deal, announced days before Trump's state visit to the Gulf, appears to violate the Trump Organization's stated pledge to avoid new foreign government transactions. The arrangement mirrors prior partnerships in Oman and Dubai where proxies were used to obscure direct state ties.

title: Government Registers '.gov' Domains for Trump Memecoin Dinner
summary: A 404 Media investigation revealed that U.S. government entities registered official domains like thetrilliondollardinner.gov and dinnerforamerica.gov around the time President Trump promoted a $TRUMP memecoin investor dinner. One domain briefly redirected to a Department of Commerce login page. The incident suggests improper use of government digital infrastructure to support a pay-to-play scheme involving Trump’s cryptocurrency, raising serious ethical and legal concerns.

title: Trump Organization Signs Golf Resort Deal with Qatar Despite Foreign Business Pledge
summary: The Trump Organization struck a deal to build a luxury golf resort in Qatar, marking its first foreign deal since Donald Trump took office for his second term. The project includes Trump-branded beachside villas and an 18-hole golf course to be built by Saudi Arabian company Dar Global, with development by Qatari Diar, which is owned by the Qatari government. This appears to violate the Trump Organization's second-term ethics pledge that it would avoid deals with foreign governments. When questioned, the Trump Organization claimed its deal was only with the Saudi firm, not the Qatari one, despite Eric Trump mentioning both companies in his statement. Ethics watchdogs criticized the deal for creating potential conflicts of interest, as it raises concerns about the president making policy decisions for personal financial gain.

title: Musk Uses Government Position to Secure Foreign Starlink Deals Amid Trade Negotiations
summary: Elon Musk has leveraged his position in the Trump administration to secure lucrative Starlink approvals in multiple countries during sensitive trade negotiations. According to reporting from the Washington Post, Musk met with representatives from Bangladesh and India at White House facilities to discuss Starlink licensing while these countries were seeking favorable trade terms with the United States. In the case of Bangladesh, a special envoy was reportedly summoned to meet with Musk after discussing cotton imports with trade officials, with the implication that Starlink approval was necessary for favorable trade treatment. Similar patterns emerged in other countries including Vietnam, Pakistan, and South Africa, where Starlink licensing had previously faced regulatory obstacles. Despite ethical concerns about using government positions for personal gain, many countries have rushed to approve Starlink licenses while seeking to avoid Trump's threatened tariffs.

title: DOGE Orders AmeriCorps to Cancel $400 Million in Grants
summary: The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) directed AmeriCorps to cancel approximately $400 million in grants, representing about 41% of the agency's $1 billion annual budget. The cuts affected 1,031 organizations and over 32,000 AmeriCorps members and senior volunteers nationwide. Earlier in April, AmeriCorps placed most of its 650 full-time staff on administrative leave and discharged members of its National Civilian Community Corps program, which sends young adults to work on disaster response and community service projects. The cuts have sparked legal challenges from 24 states and Washington D.C., who sued the Trump administration accusing DOGE of unlawfully dismantling the agency. Several Republican lawmakers, including Senator Bill Cassidy of Louisiana, have also expressed concern about the cuts.

title: Social Security Administration Falsely Designates Thousands of Immigrants as Dead
summary: The Social Security Administration has falsely added over 6,000 legally present immigrants to the agency's Death Master File at the direction of the Department of Homeland Security and DOGE. This move effectively cuts off these individuals from employment, banking services, and government benefits in what officials described as an effort to pressure them to leave the country. Internal documents revealed that those falsely listed as dead included children as young as 13, elderly people in their 70s and 80s, and a Haitian asylum seeker. When dozens of these individuals appeared at Social Security offices with identification proving they were alive, some were reinstated in the system. The White House defended the action, claiming the individuals were no longer eligible for benefits after their legal status was terminated, although they offered no evidence of alleged terrorist links or criminal records.

title: Trump questions constitutional due process rights in NBC interview
summary: During an NBC interview, President Trump stated he did not know if people in the US deserved due legal process, which is guaranteed by the Constitution. When asked if he agreed that everyone in the US deserves due process, Trump answered: "I don't know, I'm not a lawyer." He justified this position by referring to "thousands of people that are... some of the worst people on Earth" and claiming he was elected to "get them the hell out of here" but "the courts are holding me from doing it." When pressed about upholding the Constitution as president, Trump responded: "I don't know. I have to respond by saying, again, I have brilliant lawyers that work for me, and they are going to obviously follow what the Supreme Court said."

title: Trump insists on making Canada the 51st US state in NBC interview
summary: In an NBC interview, President Trump reiterated his desire to make Canada the 51st US state, despite Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney's recent election victory that was largely based on opposing Trump's geopolitical and economic threats. When asked if he would discuss annexing Canada with Carney during an upcoming meeting, Trump said he would "always talk about that" because "We subsidise Canada to the tune of $200bn a year. We don't need anything that they have." Trump claimed that "If Canada was a state it wouldn't cost us. It would be great... it would be a cherished state." While stating it was "highly unlikely" the US would use military force to take over Canada, he was more open to that possibility regarding Greenland, saying: "I don't say I'm going to do it, but I don't rule out anything. No, not there. We need Greenland very badly."

title: DOJ dismantled under Trump's second term through politically motivated actions
summary: A detailed analysis in The Atlantic reveals how the Department of Justice has been systematically dismantled under Trump's second administration through three key tactics: targeting political opponents with investigations, rewarding allies through case dismissals and favorable treatment, and eliminating internal opposition from career staff. Among the most egregious examples: DOJ investigating Chris Krebs and Miles Taylor for perceived disloyalty; Attorney General Pam Bondi launching probes into states refusing to participate in mass deportation efforts; the dismissal of corruption charges against New York Mayor Eric Adams after he supported Trump's immigration agenda; and the firing or reassignment of dozens of career DOJ officials who had previously investigated Trump or his allies.

title: DOGE Expanding AI Implementation Across Federal Agencies Despite Concerns
summary: An investigation by Wired reveals that Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) is rapidly implementing artificial intelligence systems across federal agencies with little oversight. At the Department of Housing and Urban Development, a college undergraduate named Christopher Sweet was tasked with using AI to identify regulations that could be eliminated or rewritten. In a separate initiative reported by Wired, DOGE recruiter Anthony Jancso is seeking engineers to deploy AI agents across federal agencies with the goal of replacing tens of thousands of government workers. Critics warn that many of these AI implementations are being rushed without proper safeguards, potentially causing significant disruption to essential government services while creating opportunities for private contractors to take over these functions.

title: DOGE Tasks College Student with Using AI to Rewrite Federal Housing Regulations
summary: A Wired investigation revealed that Christopher Sweet, a third-year University of Chicago student without government experience, was hired by Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) to lead an AI-driven initiative to rewrite regulations at the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). Sweet, who has not yet completed his undergraduate degree, was introduced as a 'special assistant' tasked with using AI to compare existing HUD regulations to their underlying laws and identify areas to be relaxed or removed. According to internal sources, Sweet's AI tool has already produced a spreadsheet with approximately 1,000 areas where HUD may have 'overreached,' suggesting replacement language. The initiative appears aligned with the Project 2025 policy document's deregulation goals, with sources indicating the model is being refined for deployment across all government agencies.

title: Trump Sons' Global Deals Funnel Millions to President Amid Second Term
summary: Eric Trump and Donald Trump Jr. have embarked on an international deal spree—launching luxury real estate projects in Dubai, Qatar, and Serbia, and promoting crypto ventures like World Liberty Financial and $Trump memecoin. These ventures, many involving foreign governments and state-backed capital, funnel millions directly to President Trump, according to his latest financial disclosures. Donald Jr. also co-founded a $500,000-a-seat private DC club named Executive Branch, pitched as a GOP power center. Ethics experts warn the family's actions amount to an unprecedented monetization of the presidency.

title: Trump Family Secures $2B Investment in World Liberty Financial from Abu Dhabi–Backed Firm
summary: Eric Trump announced at the Token 2049 crypto summit in Dubai that a venture capital firm backed by the Abu Dhabi government will invest $2 billion in World Liberty Financial, the Trump family's crypto venture. The investment will use World Liberty’s own digital currency product and is projected to yield hundreds of millions in fees and token revenue for the Trump family and its partners. The deal was announced while Eric Trump sat on stage next to co-founder Zach Witkoff. Ethics experts warn that the use of foreign sovereign wealth to enrich the sitting president’s family during his term raises major conflict of interest concerns.

title: Trump Jr. Launches $500K Invitation-Only DC Club for MAGA Donors and Insiders
summary: Donald Trump Jr. co-founded Executive Branch, a new $500,000-per-seat invitation-only private club in Georgetown designed as a gathering place for elite Trump allies. Modeled after the former Trump International Hotel’s lobby culture, the club will include bars, a restaurant, a boardroom, and serve as a social hub for MAGA-aligned executives, officials, and crypto insiders. Founding members include crypto moguls Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, investor David Sacks, and lobbyist Jeff Miller. The club’s creation raises red flags about access-for-sale and conflicts of interest given that some founding members were previously under SEC scrutiny until Trump-appointed officials halted enforcement. The Trump Organization confirmed the president's son is one of the primary stakeholders.

title: GENIUS Act Stalls in Senate Over Trump Family Crypto Conflicts
summary: Senate Democrats abruptly withdrew support for the bipartisan GENIUS Act—a stablecoin bill—after revelations that the Trump family’s crypto firm, World Liberty Financial, stands to benefit from provisions in the legislation. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and Senators Warren and Merkley raised concerns that the bill, if passed, would effectively enrich the president and his family through their USD1 stablecoin and a $2 billion deal with an Abu Dhabi-backed fund. The shift in support jeopardizes passage of the crypto industry's top legislative priority.

title: Senators Warren and Merkley Demand Ethics Probe into Trump Crypto Deals
summary: Senators Elizabeth Warren and Jeff Merkley formally requested an investigation by the Office of Government Ethics into the Trump family's crypto dealings. Their letter cited 'a startling degree of foreign influence and the potential for a quid pro quo' following a $2 billion Abu Dhabi transaction involving the Trump-backed firm World Liberty Financial. This followed the firm’s launch of the USD1 stablecoin, which would benefit from legislation Trump has championed. Lawmakers expressed concern that the president is using regulatory and legislative tools to personally profit.

title: Trump Hosts $1.5 Million Crypto Fundraiser at Virginia Golf Club Amid Senate Scrutiny
summary: As Senate Democrats moved to block a crypto bill benefiting his family's ventures, President Trump hosted a $1.5 million-per-person fundraiser for crypto donors at his Virginia golf club. The event was sponsored by cryptocurrency executives and came days after World Liberty Financial secured a $2 billion deal involving USD1, the Trump family’s stablecoin. The timing raised alarms among ethics watchdogs, who say the administration is blurring the line between policymaking and personal enrichment.

title: DOGE Contractor Recruits AI Agents to Replace Tens of Thousands of Federal Employees
summary: WIRED revealed that Anthony Jancso, an early DOGE recruiter and cofounder of the tech startup AccelerateX, is hiring technologists for a project to deploy AI agents across U.S. federal agencies. In a Slack post to Palantir alumni, Jancso claimed that more than 70,000 federal jobs could be replaced through AI automation. The project, aligned with DOGE’s broader efficiency goals, is being promoted without requiring security clearances and has ties to Palantir and OpenAI programs. Experts, former contractors, and public servants criticized the plan as overhyped and reckless, citing risks to governance and policy implementation.

title: FAA Staffing Crisis Reflects Systemic Failures Under Trump Administration
summary: The recent meltdown at Newark Liberty International Airport, marked by over 200 flight delays and cancellations, underscores a broader pattern of systemic failures within the FAA. The crisis was precipitated by a significant shortage of air traffic controllers, with more than 20% reportedly taking leave due to stress from repeated system outages. This staffing shortfall is part of a larger trend following the Trump administration's mass firings of FAA employees, including safety-critical personnel. Despite acknowledging the problem, the administration's efforts to recruit and retain controllers have been insufficient, leading to widespread disruptions and raising serious concerns about aviation safety nationwide.

title: FAA Meltdown at Newark Sparks Flight Chaos After Mass Firings
summary: Flight operations at Newark Liberty International Airport collapsed as over 210 flights were delayed and 88 canceled due to a severe shortage of FAA air traffic controllers. United Airlines canceled 35 roundtrips, blaming years of government inaction and multiple system failures. The Guardian confirmed that over 20% of controllers walked off the job in recent days, with whistleblowers calling the airport unsafe. The crisis occurred amid the Trump administration's mass firing of FAA safety staff, part of its broader purge of federal employees. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy acknowledged the agency is years away from full staffing. Critics warn the staffing collapse reflects deliberate undermining of public-sector capacity and aviation safety.

title: Declassified Memo Contradicts Trump on Venezuelan Gang Ties Used to Justify Mass Deportations
summary: A newly declassified intelligence memo shows that U.S. spy agencies unanimously concluded Venezuela's government does not control or direct the Tren de Aragua gang—undermining the Trump administration's claim that Maduro was using the gang to destabilize the United States. That claim served as the basis for invoking the 1798 Alien Enemies Act to deport Venezuelans without due process to a prison in El Salvador. The FBI offered a partial dissent, but the rest of the intelligence community rejected it as not credible. The memo's release supports prior reporting by the New York Times and Washington Post and raises legal questions about ongoing prosecutions of government leakers and the administration's threats to roll back press freedoms.

title: Trump Administration's Use of Alien Enemies Act Undermined by Intelligence Findings
summary: The declassification of a U.S. intelligence memo confirms that the Trump administration's claim—that Venezuela's government directed the Tren de Aragua gang to infiltrate the United States—was rejected by nearly all U.S. spy agencies. Despite that, the White House invoked the Alien Enemies Act to justify mass deportations of Venezuelan migrants to El Salvador’s CECOT prison without due process. The move marked only the fourth use of the 1798 law in American history, and the first outside a formally declared war. Legal experts and civil liberties groups argue the administration's use of the statute represents a deliberate distortion of its intent, transforming a wartime authority into a tool for sweeping domestic immigration enforcement. The administration has since doubled down on its narrative, while threatening journalists and suppressing press freedoms.

title: Trump Administration Freezes FCPA Enforcement, Prompting International Anti-Corruption Realignment
summary: The Trump administration has formally frozen enforcement of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) beyond the initial 180-day suspension, triggering alarm among transparency advocates. A new National Whistleblower Center report highlights that U.S. withdrawal from global anti-bribery leadership has spurred allied liberal democracies—including France, the U.K., and Switzerland—to announce a new joint task force in late March. Dubbed a 'Reverse Marshall Plan,' the initiative aims to fill the enforcement void by adapting U.S.-style whistleblower protections and prosecutorial models abroad. Experts warn the FCPA freeze signals a retreat from decades of bipartisan anti-corruption leadership.

title: TeleMessage Hack Compromises Government Communications
summary: TeleMessage, a messaging app used by U.S. government officials, suspended services after reports of a data breach. The app, resembling Signal, was reportedly compromised by hackers, raising national security concerns about the security of official communications.

title: Trump Organization Partners with Qatari Diar and Dar Global for $5.5B Golf Resort
summary: The Trump Organization announced a partnership with Qatari Diar and Saudi firm Dar Global to develop a $5.5 billion luxury golf resort in Qatar. The deal raises ethical concerns due to Trump's previous pledge to avoid foreign government-linked business ventures during his presidency.

title: Trump Orders Reopening of Alcatraz Prison
summary: President Donald Trump announced plans to reopen and expand the historic Alcatraz prison to detain America's most dangerous criminals. Critics argue the move is symbolic and impractical, given Alcatraz's current status as a national park and tourist attraction. The Bureau of Prisons faces logistical challenges in implementing the directive.

title: Elon Musk Exits DOGE Amid Golden Dome Windfall and Operational Failures
summary: Elon Musk's resignation from the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) marks the collapse of a flagship Trump initiative that failed to deliver promised $2 trillion in savings. Instead, it demoralized federal workers and left a trail of operational disruptions. Meanwhile, Musk’s company SpaceX is poised to be the biggest financial winner from Trump's 'Golden Dome' missile defense project—a multi-billion-dollar satellite-based shield modeled on Israel's Iron Dome. SpaceX has partnered with Palantir and Anduril to form a Golden Dome consortium, raising concerns about competitive bidding, cronyism, and insider access. The project could become one of the largest public tech expenditures in decades. Musk's departure comes amid personal reputational damage, including Tesla boycotts and backlash to far-right content moderation policies on X.

title: Insiders Make $100M in Pre-Launch Trading of Melania Trump Memecoin
summary: A Financial Times investigation found that 24 crypto wallets acquired $2.6 million in $MELANIA tokens just minutes before the memecoin’s official announcement by Melania Trump, generating $99.6 million in profits. One wallet made $39 million within 24 hours. The behavior strongly suggests insider access and market manipulation. The launch organizers have withdrawn at least $64.7 million in profit from sales and fees. Unlike securities, memecoins like $MELANIA are unregulated and not subject to federal disclosure or insider trading laws. The launch follows a growing trend of Trump family-linked crypto schemes enriching early backers without oversight.

title: Hegseth Used Signal to Direct Pentagon Business and Alert Foreign Governments
summary: A Wall Street Journal investigation revealed that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth operated at least a dozen Signal chat groups to manage official Pentagon business, including sensitive communications about U.S. military operations. In one case, Hegseth directed aides to inform foreign governments about an active strike. An aide posted details about the March 15 Yemen attack—including targets and aircraft types—into a Signal chat involving Hegseth’s wife, brother, and lawyer. Hegseth also shared information about foreign travel, Pentagon personnel matters, and scheduling via the encrypted app. His actions may violate the 2023 Pentagon directive prohibiting use of Signal for non-public official business and raise concerns about legal compliance with records preservation laws.

title: WSJ Series Documents Elon Musk's Unchecked Power Across U.S. Business and Government
summary: A Pulitzer Prize winning investigation by the Wall Street Journal chronicles Elon Musk's rise as a state-embedded oligarch wielding extraordinary unchecked power across U.S. politics, business, and government. The WSJ series documents Musk's illegal drug use while managing federally regulated companies, secret backchannel communications with Vladimir Putin, a $45M/month funding commitment to a pro-Trump super PAC, financial entanglements with Tesla directors, alleged sexual misconduct at SpaceX, and environmental violations at Tesla factories. These revelations paint a portrait of Musk as a figure operating above institutional guardrails, enabled by his proximity to the Trump White House and regulatory capture of critical agencies.

title: Trump Crypto Dinner Sparks Constitutional Concerns Over Emoluments Violations
summary: WIRED reports that President Trump's April 23 announcement offering a private dinner to top $TRUMP coin holders may violate constitutional prohibitions on domestic and foreign emoluments. Legal experts say the event transforms the memecoin into a 'utility token' by providing access to the president in exchange for investment. The Trump Organization controls 80% of the token’s supply and profits from trading volume, raising questions about bribery, pay-to-play politics, and illicit foreign influence. Senator Jon Ossoff has called for impeachment proceedings, while watchdogs warn the dinner sets a dangerous precedent for monetizing executive access.

title: Atlantic Analysis Reveals DOGE's Claimed $165B in Cuts Actually Amount to Less Than 0.2% of Federal Budget
summary: An investigation by The Atlantic exposed that despite claiming $165 billion in budget savings, the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) has delivered verifiable cuts of just $15 billion—approximately 0.2% of federal spending. Treasury Department data shows federal outlays actually increased by $86 billion (7%) compared to the previous year. DOGE's accounting methods included claiming credit for the full value of canceled contracts rather than actual expenditures, counting the same cuts multiple times, and including contracts that expired decades ago. Meanwhile, the administration's targeted cuts to public health and foreign aid programs have caused significant disruptions while saving only $2.1 billion monthly.

title: Qatar Plans to Gift Trump $400M Luxury Jet for Use as Air Force One and Later His Library
summary: The Trump administration planned to accept a luxury Boeing 747-8 worth $400 million from Qatar's royal family to serve as Air Force One, with the plane later transferring to Trump's presidential library. Ethics experts and lawmakers condemned the arrangement as a potential emoluments clause violation, citing Trump's business interests in the region, including a recently announced Trump golf resort in Qatar. When questioned about ethical concerns, Trump responded angrily, calling those who objected 'stupid' and saying only someone 'stupid' would turn down such an offer. The deal reflects a broader pattern of quid pro quo arrangements with foreign governments—including Qatar and El Salvador—where lucrative business partnerships or crypto cooperation coincided with favorable U.S. policy treatment or immigration enforcement assistance.

title: Foreign Buyers Exploit Trump Crypto Dinner Contest to Gain Presidential Access
summary: An investigation by The New York Times revealed that foreign investors dominated a contest to win dinner with President Trump through his family's cryptocurrency, with several Asian crypto companies explicitly stating they sought to influence U.S. policy. The contest also contained a loophole allowing at least 17 winners to sell all their $TRUMP coins while still securing White House access. Senator Jeff Merkley called it 'the White House and President Trump selling access to the government and himself for personal profit,' while the influx of foreign influence derailed bipartisan crypto legislation in Congress.

title: Trump Memecoin Dinner Winners Include Foreign Actors Seeking Policy Influence
summary: The New York Times revealed that the 220 winners of President Trump's cryptocurrency dinner contest included numerous foreign entities explicitly seeking to influence U.S. policy. Among the winners were Singapore-based MemeCore, which stated it wanted to share its 'vision and mission' with Trump, and crypto mogul Justin Sun, previously targeted by an SEC fraud suit. The contest enabled foreign nationals to bypass traditional restrictions on political donations by purchasing Trump's family cryptocurrency. Senator Jeff Merkley denounced the arrangement as 'this kind of grift' while introducing legislation to ban presidents from profiting from crypto sales.

title: Turkish Doctoral Student Rümeysa Öztürk Released After Court Rules Detention Was Politically Motivated
summary: A federal judge ordered the release of Rümeysa Öztürk, the Tufts University doctoral student who had been detained for over a month in a Louisiana ICE facility after writing an essay critical of Israel. Judge Fernando Rodriguez ruled that her detention likely stemmed from unconstitutional retaliation for protected political speech. The case sparked widespread protests on college campuses and condemnation from academic institutions across the country. Following her release, Öztürk described inhumane conditions at the detention center and said she would continue to advocate for academic freedom.

title: Families Sue El Salvador for Imprisoning Venezuelans Deported from US Without Due Process
summary: A coalition of migrant rights lawyers filed a lawsuit with the Inter-American Commission of Human Rights on behalf of 18 Venezuelan nationals who were deported from the US and imprisoned in El Salvador's notorious CECOT maximum-security prison. Many of the detainees had pending or approved asylum applications in the US but were deported without due process as part of a deal between the Trump administration and Salvadoran President Nayib Bukele. Lawyers reported that families have had no contact with their relatives for nearly two months, and a New York Times investigation found most of the men had no criminal record or only minor infractions despite being labeled as gang members.

title: DOGE's 'Zombie Contracts': 44 Canceled Agreements Quietly Reinstated by Agencies
summary: A New York Times investigation revealed that at least 44 government contracts claimed as 'terminated' on DOGE's 'Wall of Receipts' had actually been reinstated by federal agencies, wiping out over $220 million in purported savings. Despite these reinstatements, Elon Musk's team continued listing 43 of these contracts as cancelled—some added weeks after being revived. Key agencies reversed cuts affecting legally mandated programs and critical services, with the Department of Veterans Affairs reinstating 16 contracts and the EPA reviving one contract after just 2.5 hours. White House spokesman Harrison Fields dismissed the findings as 'very, very small potatoes' compared to DOGE's claimed $165 billion in total savings.

title: Newark Airport Crisis: Air Traffic Control System Failures Lead to Mass Flight Disruptions
summary: Air traffic controllers at Newark Liberty International Airport experienced terrifying system failures where they temporarily lost radar and radio contact with aircraft, leaving them unable to direct planes and prevent potential collisions. According to The New York Times, these technology breakdowns led to extreme anxiety among controllers, with some requiring mental health leave, resulting in critical staffing shortages and over 1,000 canceled or delayed flights. The Federal Aviation Administration acknowledged that only 16 certified controllers were available when more than double that number were needed. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy, overseeing an agency that faced similar technical failures in August 2024, announced plans for 'a brand-new air traffic control system' following these incidents and a deadly midair collision earlier this year.

title: DOGE Creates Centralized Database of Citizens' Personal Information, Bypassing Privacy Protections
summary: The Washington Post revealed that Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency is building a centralized database containing sensitive personal information about millions of Americans, including Social Security numbers, medical diagnoses, tax records, and employment histories. Government workers reported that DOGE is bypassing traditional privacy safeguards, with some employees even disabling security tracking logs while accessing massive federal databases. Cybersecurity experts warned that consolidating these previously separated systems creates significant security vulnerabilities, with former NSA hacker Jake Williams noting the increased risk of foreign adversaries accessing this 'tempting target.' Rep. Gerry Connolly has asked the Social Security Inspector General to investigate whistleblower concerns, while a federal court has issued a temporary injunction against DOGE accessing certain sensitive data.

title: Musk Uses Government Position to Secure Foreign Starlink Approvals Amid Trade Negotiations
summary: Internal State Department cables obtained by The Washington Post revealed that countries facing Trump's tariffs have rushed to approve Elon Musk's Starlink satellite service while seeking favorable trade terms. Officials from Lesotho, India, Cambodia, Bangladesh, and Vietnam granted Starlink licenses shortly after facing tariff threats, with one Cambodian official explicitly recommending 'expeditiously approving Starlink's market entry request' to smooth relations with the administration. Secretary of State Marco Rubio has instructed diplomats worldwide to promote Starlink by name, representing a significant escalation from previous administrations' more general support for American satellite companies. While the White House denied explicit quid pro quo arrangements, experts noted foreign officials 'can see their life might be a lot easier if seen as getting along with Elon Musk.'

title: Chinese-Linked TikTok Company Announces $300M Investment in Trump's Cryptocurrency
summary: The New York Times reported that GD Culture Group, a struggling Nasdaq-listed company with Chinese subsidiaries and TikTok business ties, announced plans to purchase up to $300 million of President Trump's $TRUMP memecoin. The company, which had zero revenue last year and only eight employees, said it would make the purchase using funds from an anonymous entity in the British Virgin Islands. Ethics experts condemned the arrangement, with former House Ethics Committee Chairman Charles Dent calling it 'completely out of bounds,' particularly as it creates a direct conflict of interest while Trump decides whether to allow TikTok to continue operating in the United States. The company's SEC filings acknowledge that 'the Chinese government may intervene or influence its operations at any time.'

title: DOGE Quietly Removes Dozens of 'Zombie Contracts' from Website After Times Exposure
summary: Following a New York Times investigation that exposed DOGE's continued claims of credit for canceled contracts that had actually been reinstated, Elon Musk's group quietly deleted 31 of these false claims from its website, removing $122 million in purported savings. However, DOGE still maintained 12 other resurrected contracts on its 'Wall of Receipts,' falsely claiming $121 million in additional savings. Despite the embarrassing correction, DOGE simultaneously added over 800 new contract terminations to its website and increased its claimed total savings from $165 billion to $170 billion. This episode represents the latest in a pattern of data manipulation, following earlier revelations that DOGE had double-counted cancellations and claimed credit for contracts that ended decades ago.

title: WIRED Investigation: Trump Crypto Dinner Requires Minimum $2 Million Investment from Foreign VIPs
summary: An investigation by WIRED revealed that attendees of President Trump's exclusive crypto dinner needed to hold at least $55,000 worth of his $TRUMP memecoin, while the 25 VIP guests attending a more intimate reception held an average of $4.3 million each. The largest investor, known only as 'Sun' and believed to be connected to Chinese billionaire Justin Sun, purchased over $19 million worth of tokens. The analysis found that approximately 35 of the 220 qualifying investors sold off their holdings immediately after securing their spots, exploiting a loophole to cash out while still gaining access to the president. Democratic lawmakers have introduced the MEME Act to prevent elected officials from releasing cryptocurrency, with Congressman Sam Liccardo telling WIRED such coins provide 'a cloak for payments from bad actors to elected officials and their family.'

title: Trump Administration Fires Copyright Office Director After AI Copyright Report, Attempts Unauthorized Takeover
summary: WIRED reported that the Trump administration fired US Copyright Office Director Shira Perlmutter one day after her office released a report questioning the legality of using copyrighted materials to train AI systems. Two administration appointees, Brian Nieves and Paul Perkins, subsequently attempted to enter the Copyright Office claiming they had been appointed to leadership roles, but were denied entry. Critics note the president lacks legal authority to fire or appoint Copyright Office leadership, as this power resides with the Librarian of Congress—who was also fired by Trump days earlier. Representative Joe Morelle stated the timing 'is surely no coincidence' and connected the firing to Perlmutter's refusal to 'rubber-stamp Elon Musk's efforts to mine troves of copyrighted works to train AI models.'

title: Wisconsin Judge Indicted by Federal Grand Jury for Allegedly Helping Immigrant Evade ICE
summary: Judge Hannah C. Dugan of the Milwaukee County Circuit Court was indicted by a federal grand jury on charges of obstruction and concealing a person from arrest after allegedly directing an undocumented immigrant to exit through a non-public door to avoid waiting federal agents. The prosecution represents a significant escalation in the administration's immigration enforcement tactics, with Attorney General Pam Bondi defending the case while over 150 former judges condemned it as 'a cynical effort' to intimidate the judiciary. Judge Dugan, who has been temporarily removed from the bench by the Wisconsin Supreme Court, maintains her innocence and plans to fight the charges.

title: 20 States Sue Trump Administration Over Threats to Withhold Funding for Immigration Non-Compliance
summary: A coalition of 20 predominantly Democratic-led states filed two federal lawsuits challenging the Trump administration's threats to withhold billions in transportation, counterterrorism, and emergency preparedness funding unless states complied with federal immigration enforcement demands. The lawsuits, led by California Attorney General Rob Bonta, characterize the administration's actions as a 'hostage scheme' that illegally usurps Congress's spending authority. This legal challenge is part of a growing pattern of state resistance to federal overreach, with similar lawsuits recently filed over threats to withhold funding from schools with diversity programs, as well as challenges to tariffs and mass firings at federal agencies like Education and Health and Human Services.

title: Commerce Secretary Lutnick's Ties to Tether and El Salvador Raise Ethical Concerns
summary: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick's connections to cryptocurrency firm Tether and its operations in El Salvador have come under scrutiny. Cantor Fitzgerald, Lutnick's former firm, holds a 5% stake in Tether and manages a significant portion of its $134 billion in assets. Tether's relocation to El Salvador, a country with crypto-friendly regulations under President Nayib Bukele, and subsequent investments—including a $775 million stake in pro-Trump platform Rumble—have raised questions about potential conflicts of interest and ethical violations within the Trump administration.

title: Commerce Secretary Lutnick Maintains Tether Ties and El Salvador Interests While Overseeing U.S. Crypto Policy
summary: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, CEO of Cantor Fitzgerald, retained extensive ties to El Salvador’s crypto ecosystem—including a 5% stake in Tether and business relationships with Nayib Bukele’s government—while overseeing the Trump administration’s international crypto policy. Ethics experts raised concerns about conflicts of interest and potential self-dealing, particularly as Lutnick promoted El Salvador as a 'model partner' in U.S. digital asset diplomacy. The revelation has prompted scrutiny from lawmakers and calls for greater transparency in Cabinet officials’ financial disclosures.

title: El Salvador Immigration Cooperation Linked to Crypto Diplomacy and Commerce Secretary’s Business Interests
summary: The Guardian reported that El Salvador's close cooperation with the Trump administration on mass Venezuelan deportations was influenced by behind-the-scenes economic negotiations tied to cryptocurrency investments. El Salvador, under President Nayib Bukele, received favorable regulatory treatment and was praised by Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick—who has financial interests in El Salvador’s crypto operations. The alignment of immigration enforcement, foreign aid, and digital currency diplomacy raised red flags among watchdog groups, suggesting the administration was blending policy incentives with financial self-interest.

title: Trump Administration Wages Multi-Agency Retaliation Campaign Against Harvard
summary: In an unprecedented use of federal power against a private university, the Trump administration has orchestrated a multi-agency crackdown on Harvard, combining legal investigations, funding cuts, and public threats to force the university to align with its ideological agenda. According to a comprehensive New York Times report, at least six federal departments and eight active investigations have targeted the school since February. Actions include the termination or suspension of over $4 billion in grants, retaliatory audits of foreign gifts, threats to revoke tax-exempt status, and scrutiny of faculty hiring, curriculum, and student speech. The pressure campaign originated from an antisemitism task force but has since widened into a political assault on what Trump officials describe as a bastion of 'liberal bias' and 'virtue signaling.' Harvard has sued the administration in federal court, arguing that the government is using funding and investigations to seize control over academic decisions in violation of the First Amendment.

title: Trump Administration Bars Harvard from Enrolling International Students
summary: In a sweeping escalation of its crackdown on elite universities, the Trump administration revoked Harvard’s certification under the Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP), blocking the school from enrolling international students. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem announced the decision via letter and social media, citing Harvard’s alleged failure to comply with reporting requirements in an ongoing investigation related to antisemitism and student visa compliance. The action affects roughly 6,800 international students—over a quarter of Harvard’s student body—and threatens a core component of the university’s academic and financial model. Harvard officials called the move unlawful and warned that it would cause serious harm to the university’s global mission and the U.S.'s standing in international education. Critics described the move as an unprecedented use of immigration enforcement to reshape higher education policy and punish political dissent.

title: House Passes Trump's Massive Tax and Immigration Bill Amid Partisan Firestorm
summary: In a razor-thin 215-214 vote, House Republicans passed President Trump's sweeping tax and immigration bill, dubbed the 'One Big Beautiful Bill.' The legislation, now heading to the Senate, includes major tax cuts, deep reductions in Medicaid and other social safety net programs, a sharp escalation of deportation powers, expanded military spending, and restrictions on student loans. It also repeals climate investments and renews funding for Trump’s border wall project. Trump praised the bill as a cornerstone of his second-term agenda and demanded swift Senate passage. Democrats uniformly opposed the package, with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer calling it 'rotten to the core' and a vehicle for enriching the wealthy while punishing the poor. The legislation also omits Trump’s promised closure of the carried-interest loophole, which drew criticism even from some conservative holdouts. Trump allies have threatened primary challenges against the two Republican defectors, signaling continued intra-party enforcement of ideological loyalty.

title: Trump Officials Initially Bar Mahmoud Khalil from Holding His Newborn Son Before Hearing
summary: One day before his immigration hearing, detained Columbia graduate Mahmoud Khalil was initially prohibited from holding his newborn son by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and its private prison contractor. His wife, Noor Abdalla, had traveled from New York to Louisiana with their month-old baby, but ICE cited 'security concerns' and a blanket no-contact policy to deny the visit. Khalil and his wife were forced to see each other through glass. The Department of Homeland Security had also previously denied Khalil’s request to be present for the birth. Public outcry over the separation and the inhumanity of the policy intensified, with his legal team describing the denial as 'deliberate cruelty.' The administration reversed course later that evening, allowing a short private visit just hours before Khalil’s May 22 hearing, signaling a reactive sensitivity to public backlash.

title: Trump Administration Persists in Deportation Case Against Mahmoud Khalil Despite Risk of Death
summary: Mahmoud Khalil, a Columbia University graduate and prominent pro-Palestinian activist, testified that deportation from the U.S. could lead to assassination or torture. Arrested without a warrant in March and held in a Louisiana ICE facility for over two months, Khalil has become a symbol of the Trump administration’s crackdown on campus dissent. At his immigration hearing, expert witnesses described his international visibility as placing him at extreme risk if deported. In a high-profile moment preceding the hearing, ICE initially blocked Khalil from holding his newborn son during a family visit—forcing the meeting to occur behind glass—but reversed that decision under sustained legal pressure and mounting public scrutiny. The private meeting occurred hours before the hearing began, reflecting the administration’s sensitivity to reputational backlash even as it pressed forward with the deportation case. A federal judge in New Jersey has temporarily blocked Khalil's removal, and appeals are ongoing. The administration continues to frame the case as part of its effort to combat antisemitism, though Khalil has consistently denounced antisemitic rhetoric.

title: Trump Administration Asks Supreme Court to Shield DOGE From Releasing Internal Records
summary: The Trump administration filed an emergency request with the Supreme Court seeking to block a lower court’s order requiring Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) to release internal documents. The lawsuit, brought by watchdog group CREW, argued that DOGE functions as a federal agency and is therefore subject to federal public records laws. A federal judge had sided with CREW in March, finding that DOGE exercises sweeping authority over the federal government and should not be exempt from transparency obligations. The administration has claimed that DOGE’s documents are 'presidential records' and therefore immune to FOIA and most judicial review until 2034. A federal appeals court had already rejected this argument and ordered DOGE to begin releasing records, prompting the administration’s petition to the high court. Legal experts warn the case could set a precedent for dramatically curbing public oversight of powerful executive entities.

title: U.S. Formally Accepts Qatar's Luxury Jet for Trump's Use as Air Force One
summary: The Department of Defense formally accepted a luxury Boeing 747-8 from the government of Qatar as a gift to the United States, prompting widespread concern from lawmakers and ethics experts. President Trump confirmed that the aircraft—previously owned by the Qatari royal family—would be retrofitted for use as Air Force One, bypassing congressional approval for a deal critics call 'the largest foreign bribe in modern history.' The Pentagon acknowledged the need for major upgrades to the plane's security systems, but senators expressed concern about cost overruns, schedule acceleration, and national security risks, including potential surveillance devices. The Air Force said it was preparing to award a classified contract to modify the jet. Despite constitutional requirements for Congress to approve such gifts, the administration maintains the plane is a gift to the government, not Trump personally. The jet has an estimated retrofit cost of over $1 billion and will become the third aircraft designated for presidential transport—far beyond standard practice.

title: Federal Judge Rules Trump Illegally Fired Civil Liberties Oversight Board Members
summary: A federal judge ruled that President Trump violated the law by firing Democratic-selected members of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board without cause. The ruling reinstates Travis LeBlanc and Edward W. Felten, who sued after their abrupt removal in January 2025 as part of a broader purge of independent oversight officials. Judge Reggie B. Walton wrote that Congress created the bipartisan board to serve as a check on executive counterterrorism powers and shielded its members from arbitrary dismissal. He called Trump’s action an unconstitutional attempt to evade oversight and erode the separation of powers. The ruling is the first permanent injunction to reverse a Trump personnel decision under his effort to challenge limits on presidential removal power. The board had been left paralyzed after the firings, unable to conduct investigations with only one member remaining. The Justice Department declined to comment.

title: Judge Threatens Contempt as Trump Administration Sends Migrants to South Sudan Despite Court Ban
summary: In a chaotic hearing, a federal judge ordered the Trump administration to retain custody of deportees after immigration lawyers revealed that a Burmese and a Vietnamese migrant were allegedly sent to South Sudan — in direct violation of a prior court order. DHS officials could not confirm the location or destination of the deportation flight, claiming the information was classified. Judge Brian Murphy warned that if the administration knowingly violated his April injunction — which banned deporting migrants to third countries without 15 days’ notice — it could constitute contempt. The administration later claimed one migrant had been sent to Myanmar, not South Sudan, but refused to disclose the second destination. The case is part of a broader pattern in which Trump officials skirt judicial oversight and deport migrants to unrelated nations including El Salvador, Panama, and Libya under wartime powers or opaque deals.

title: Trump Hosts $TRUMP Coin Investors at Private Dinner as Family Profits from Crypto Surge
summary: President Trump hosted a private dinner at his Northern Virginia golf club for the top 220 investors in his meme coin, $TRUMP, offering personal access and luxury watches to top contributors. The event coincided with Bitcoin’s record-breaking surge and the Senate's advancement of key pro-crypto legislation. Critics, including Sen. Richard Blumenthal, called the dinner a pay-to-play scheme that 'puts a for sale sign on the White House.' The Trump family controls a majority stake in World Liberty Financial, which issues the stablecoin USD1. That coin was recently used in a $2 billion investment deal with Binance. Meanwhile, Trump has appointed crypto allies to key positions, signed executive orders promoting Bitcoin, and seen the SEC drop cases against prominent industry figures. Despite claims that the president is attending in his 'personal capacity,' ethics experts warn that his financial entanglements risk corrupting both governance and the credibility of the cryptocurrency industry.

title: Federal Judge Blocks DOGE Takeover of U.S. Institute of Peace, Calls Move 'Unlawful'
summary: In a scathing opinion, Judge Beryl Howell ruled that DOGE's takeover of the U.S. Institute of Peace (USIP) — including the forced removal of board members, termination of staff, and attempted asset transfer of the $500 million headquarters — was unlawful and void. The Trump administration had tried to dissolve the congressionally chartered institute via executive order, but the court found the DOGE-led actions to be a 'gross usurpation of power.' Court documents detail how federal agents helped DOGE operatives enter USIP facilities, terminate employees, and transfer assets to the General Services Administration, including the Institute’s $25 million endowment. The ruling reinstated the original USIP board and barred the administration from maintaining access to any USIP resources. This marks one of the most definitive legal repudiations of DOGE’s power grab across the federal government.

title: Tornado Death Toll Highlights Risks of DOGE Cuts to Emergency Weather Systems
summary: A devastating series of tornadoes across Missouri, Kentucky, and Virginia killed 42 people in a single weekend, underscoring growing concerns over degraded federal disaster readiness under the Trump administration. A report by *The Atlantic* warns that staffing cuts imposed by the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), run by Elon Musk and Donald Trump, have compromised the forecasting and alert capabilities of the National Weather Service and NOAA. As hurricane season looms, about 40% of local NWS offices face critical staffing gaps. Experts warn that these cuts may reduce the precious seconds Americans have to seek shelter in extreme weather events.

title: Trump's Gulf Trip Spurs Foreign Deals for Musk Family, Including New Starlink and Crypto Projects
summary: President Trump's state visit to Saudi Arabia and the UAE doubled as a lucrative opportunity for Elon Musk and his family to announce and solidify business deals across the Gulf region. During the trip, SpaceX secured approval to expand Starlink services in Saudi Arabia, Neuralink launched a new trial partnership in Abu Dhabi, and Musk’s tunneling company signaled plans for a Saudi collaboration. Meanwhile, Musk's brother and father promoted drone light shows and a 'Musk Tower' crypto-funded tech hub, respectively. The Musk family's simultaneous presence alongside Trump officials raised concerns about blurred lines between U.S. diplomacy and private gain.

title: Trump's Qatar Jet Gift Traced to Witkoff Backchannels and Delays in Air Force One Replacement
summary: A New York Times investigation details how President Trump, frustrated by Boeing delays, pursued a luxury 747-8 from Qatar as an interim Air Force One—with help from real estate ally and Middle East envoy Steven Witkoff. Originally offered for sale, the jet was later presented as a 'gift, free of charge' by Qatar, triggering bipartisan ethics concerns. The plane, opulently outfitted and once used by Qatar's royal family, was flown to Florida at Trump's request. Despite claims it would save time and money, Pentagon officials estimate retrofitting the aircraft for presidential use would cost over $1 billion and take years, raising questions about the arrangement's feasibility and legality.

title: Trump Administration Moves to Dismantle CFPB, Triggering Internal Staff Uprising and Legal Block
summary: In a dramatic escalation, the Trump administration attempted to fire over 1,500 of the 1,700 employees at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the agency created after the 2008 financial crisis to protect consumers from predatory financial practices. The plan was temporarily halted by a federal judge, but insiders warn that the CFPB is already 'handcuffed' and unable to perform basic functions. Staff say the Department of Government Efficiency, led by interim director Russ Vought, is using the pretext of reform to gut protections for American borrowers. Plans to eliminate 70 regulatory policies—including consumer credit rules for medical debt—continue amid accusations of sabotage. Vought is seeking to dismantle the agency before his temporary appointment expires under Project 2025.

title: Trump Sells Access to Crypto Investors via Meme Coin Gala, Raising Alarms About Foreign Influence and Anonymity
summary: A Washington Post exposé reveals that dozens of largely anonymous crypto investors—many from China and Southeast Asia—won access to a private gala with President Trump by purchasing millions in 'Trump meme coins.' The top 220 buyers were invited to a no-press dinner at Trump National Golf Club, with many identities masked by untraceable wallets. At least half of the top invitees used offshore exchanges that reject U.S. customers. Critics—including Sen. Chris Murphy—warned the scheme could let authoritarian regimes or opaque firms buy policy influence. One attendee, a crypto investor known as 'Ogle,' is also tied to World Liberty Financial, which just announced a $2B crypto deal involving Binance and an Emirati firm with Trump family links. The Trump team has earned over $43 million in transaction fees since the coin launched in January.

title: Senators Demand Transparency on Trump's Crypto Gala, Citing Foreign Influence and National Security Risks
summary: Senator Chris Murphy, joined by Senators Elizabeth Warren, Jeff Merkley, Richard Blumenthal, and Representative Sam Liccardo, held a press conference condemning President Trump's private dinner with top investors of his $TRUMP meme coin. The lawmakers demanded the release of the attendees' names, the amounts they paid, and any favors they might be receiving in return. They expressed grave concerns over the anonymity of the investors, many of whom are linked to foreign entities, and the potential national security risks posed by such undisclosed access to the President. The event, held at Trump's golf club in Sterling, Virginia, was criticized as a 'pay-to-play' scheme that undermines democratic principles and potentially violates federal ethics laws.

title: Judge Rules Trump Administration Illegally Dismantled U.S. Institute of Peace
summary: A federal judge ruled that President Trump and the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) unlawfully dismantled the U.S. Institute of Peace (USIP), an independent nonprofit established by Congress. Judge Beryl Howell called the seizure of the organization’s building by DOGE agents—aided by the FBI and D.C. police—a 'gross usurpation of power.' Trump had replaced USIP leadership with a DOGE agent, terminated its board without legal authority, and transferred the headquarters to the GSA, all in violation of the 1984 law protecting its independence. The ruling voids all resulting actions and reaffirms the institute’s independent legal status. The White House has 30 days to appeal.

title: Supreme Court Allows Trump to Lift Deportation Protections for 350,000 Venezuelans
summary: The Supreme Court permitted the Trump administration to terminate Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for nearly 350,000 Venezuelans, reversing a lower court's block. The unsigned emergency order allows deportations to proceed while litigation continues. Civil rights attorneys called the move the largest single removal of immigration protection in modern U.S. history.
