DHS Secretary Kristi Noem’s decision to end TPS was previously ruled 'arbitrary and capricious' and racially biased by a federal judge, who warned of catastrophic impacts on families, the economy, and public health. Critics argue the Supreme Court’s brief order offers no reasoning and sets a dangerous precedent for unchecked executive immigration power.

title: Trump Hosts Controversial Crypto Dinner Amid Ethics Concerns
summary: On May 22, 2025, President Donald Trump hosted an exclusive dinner at his Virginia golf club for the top 220 holders of his meme cryptocurrency, $TRUMP. Attendees secured their invitations by purchasing significant amounts of the token, with the top 25 investors, including Chinese crypto mogul Justin Sun, gaining access to a private reception. Collectively, participants spent approximately $394 million on the coin, raising serious ethical and legal questions about pay-to-play politics, foreign influence, and potential violations of the Constitution's Emoluments Clause. Critics, including Senators Elizabeth Warren and Chris Murphy, have called for investigations into the blending of Trump's private business interests with his presidential duties. The White House maintains that the event was a private affair, but bipartisan concern over the implications for political integrity and national security continues to grow.

title: Trump Administration Cancels VA Suicide Prevention and Cancer Research Projects at Harvard
summary: As part of its broader campaign against Harvard University, the Trump administration began canceling multiple Department of Veterans Affairs research contracts with the university, including those focused on suicide prevention, toxic exposure, and prostate cancer screening. Internal VA emails obtained by The New York Times reveal that senior officials warned the terminations would increase preventable veteran suicides and hinder access to clinical trials. Despite internal objections, the administration, under pressure from Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency, is pushing forward with mass contract cancellations and workforce reductions. Over $2.7 billion in Harvard-related federal research grants have been frozen or revoked, with VA projects now caught in the political crossfire. Harvard has sued to stop the cuts.

title: Trump Administration Fires Over One-Third of Voice of America Staff, Puts Building Up for Sale
summary: The Trump administration fired nearly 600 employees—over one-third of Voice of America’s workforce—in a sweeping move to dismantle the independent news organization. The layoffs primarily affected journalists, including those from repressive regimes who must now leave the U.S. due to their visa status. The action follows an earlier executive order to defund the U.S. Agency for Global Media and shutter affiliated newsrooms. A federal court ruling had required the administration to preserve VOA news operations, but a recent appeals court decision allowed certain firings to proceed. The administration has also listed VOA’s Washington headquarters for sale and announced plans to replace some programming with content from the pro-Trump outlet One America News. Critics warn the purge represents a grave threat to U.S. soft power and press freedom abroad.

title: Attorney General Pam Bondi Sold Trump Media Stock on Same Day Tariffs Crashed Markets
summary: Financial disclosures reveal that Attorney General Pam Bondi sold between $1 million and $5 million in Trump Media stock on April 2—the same day President Trump announced surprise global tariffs that caused a sharp drop in stock prices. The timing raised concerns about possible insider trading, though Bondi was legally required to divest her shares within 90 days of taking office. The stock lost 15% of its value after the announcement, then rebounded when Trump reversed course. Bondi, a longtime Trump ally, previously earned millions from consulting for Trump Media and lobbying with firms close to the president. Her spokesman did not respond to requests for comment. The Office of Government Ethics has not announced an investigation.

title: Disability Rights Activists Arrested Protesting Medicaid Cuts in Trump’s Omnibus Bill
summary: Twenty-five disability rights activists, many in wheelchairs, were arrested inside a House committee hearing as Republican lawmakers advanced major cuts to Medicaid under Trump’s so-called 'One Big Beautiful Bill.' Protesters from the group ADAPT disrupted markup proceedings chanting 'no cuts to Medicaid' and 'waste, fraud, and abuse, my ass,' as GOP leadership framed the cuts as targeting inefficiency. The bill extends Trump-era tax cuts for the wealthy while slashing health care, SNAP, and climate programs. A CBO analysis found the proposed Medicaid cuts would strip health coverage from over 10 million Americans in the next decade.

title: Musk Leverages DOGE-Gathered Government Data to Boost xAI Valuation in Saudi Deal
summary: While stepping back from formal DOGE operations, Elon Musk traveled with President Trump to Saudi Arabia, where he joined AI leaders like Sam Altman and Jensen Huang in courting Saudi investment. Cybersecurity experts warn that Musk’s AI company, xAI—now valued at up to $120 billion—is built in part on data mined from U.S. government systems while Musk led the Department of Government Efficiency. The administration's recent firings of the Librarian of Congress and Register of Copyrights, both critics of unauthorized AI training, raised further alarms about government-enabled profiteering. Musk reportedly pitched xAI as a vehicle for Saudi investment in a $600 billion package negotiated during the visit.

title: Musk Steps Back from DOGE as Congressional Caucus Collapses
summary: After months of leading the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) and accessing sensitive federal data, Elon Musk has reportedly stepped back from formal duties—shifting focus to raising a $120 billion valuation for his private AI firm, xAI. Meanwhile, the House DOGE Caucus, created to collaborate with Musk, has collapsed. Rep. Jared Moskowitz (D-FL) confirmed that the caucus is 'dead... defunct' and held only two meetings in five months. The public backlash over airport meltdowns, AI surveillance, and mass firings is believed to have eroded congressional support.

title: Trump Fires Top Intelligence Analysts After Report Contradicts Venezuela-Gang Claims
summary: President Trump's Director of National Intelligence, Tulsi Gabbard, fired acting NIC chair Michael Collins and his deputy after they authored an assessment refuting the claim that Venezuela is directing the Tren de Aragua gang. The administration had used that claim to invoke the Alien Enemies Act and deport Venezuelan migrants to El Salvador's CECOT prison. Gabbard justified the purge as part of an effort to stop 'politicization' of intelligence, though critics see it as retaliation for contradicting the administration's deportation narrative.

title: DOJ Announces Plan to Publicly 'Shame' Opponents Even Without Charges
summary: In a dramatic break with prior Department of Justice norms, Trump appointee Ed Martin announced a new policy to 'name and shame' political opponents even when prosecutors lack the evidence to file criminal charges. The program, under the DOJ's 'Weaponization Working Group,' aims to convict individuals 'in the court of public opinion.' Senate Republicans previously blocked Martin’s U.S. attorney nomination, but Trump installed him in this new role via executive action. Legal scholars and former DOJ officials denounced the plan as a threat to civil liberties and due process.

title: Appeals Court Rules Watchdog Group Can Proceed with Lawsuit for DOGE Records
summary: A federal appeals court ruled that the Trump administration must resume efforts to disclose internal records from the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) to the watchdog group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW). The ruling rejects the government's claim that DOGE is exempt from Freedom of Information Act requirements due to its alleged status as part of the president's personal staff. The court found the government had 'forfeited' key arguments and ordered Elon Musk’s team to begin cooperating with CREW. The decision could force DOGE to reveal details about its structure, members, and its sweeping role in agency cuts, database access, and regulatory changes.

title: Federal Judge Orders Georgetown Scholar Released, Citing First Amendment Violations
summary: A federal judge ordered the release of Badar Khan Suri, an Indian postdoctoral fellow at Georgetown University, who was detained for over two months by ICE despite no criminal charges. Judge Patricia Giles ruled from the bench that the Trump administration had offered no evidence justifying Suri’s detention and that his arrest was likely retaliatory, violating his First Amendment rights. Suri was reportedly targeted due to his wife’s Palestinian background and family ties, though he had never participated in a protest. The judge explicitly stated that the First Amendment protects noncitizens and emphasized that detaining critics of U.S. policy 'for punitive reasons' creates a chilling effect on academic speech. The case is part of a broader crackdown on foreign scholars with perceived pro-Palestinian views.

title: Crypto Miner Backed by Trump Sons to List on Nasdaq Amid Deregulation Push
summary: American Bitcoin, a cryptocurrency mining firm backed by Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump, will go public on Nasdaq following a merger with Gryphon Digital Mining. The company was formed in March and rebranded from American Data Centers—originally a subsidiary of Dominari Holdings, where the Trump sons hold advisory roles. Eric Trump will stay on as Chief Strategy Officer. The company markets itself as the most 'investable Bitcoin accumulation platform' and aims to profit from President Trump's deregulation of the crypto sector. The move mirrors MicroStrategy’s Bitcoin-hoarding strategy, now being copied by Trump-linked ventures. Also cited: Brandon Lutnick, son of Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, who is launching an $11B bitcoin SPAC with Tether and SoftBank. The same day, FT revealed that a small group of traders had made nearly $100 million off pre-announcement purchases of Melania Trump’s memecoin.

title: Tulsi Gabbard Fires Top Intelligence Officials Who Authored Venezuela Deportation Memo
summary: Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard fired the chair and deputy of the National Intelligence Council (NIC) after their agency produced an assessment contradicting the Trump administration’s claim that Venezuela is directing Tren de Aragua gang activity. The April 7 report found no credible evidence that the Venezuelan government was orchestrating migration via the gang—undermining Trump’s legal basis for invoking the Alien Enemies Act to deport thousands of Venezuelans. Critics condemned the firings as political retaliation against independent analysis. Former NIC chair Christopher Kojm warned the move would chill honest assessments and damage U.S. intelligence. Gabbard also announced plans to relocate the NIC from CIA headquarters to the ODNI’s main campus, consolidating Trump-aligned control over top-level intelligence briefings.

title: Federal Judge Blocks Mass Trump Layoffs and Agency Closures
summary: Judge Susan Illston of the U.S. District Court in California extended an injunction blocking the Trump administration from proceeding with mass layoffs at 22 federal agencies, including Housing and Urban Development, State, Treasury, and Veterans Affairs. The ruling also prohibits the administration from shutting down or relocating programs and offices while the case is pending. The layoffs are part of a broader initiative by the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), which has faced mounting legal challenges for bypassing procedural norms and targeting career civil servants.

title: Witkoff Family Brokers Foreign Crypto Deals While Overseeing Trump Diplomacy
summary: A Wall Street Journal investigation revealed that Steve Witkoff, Trump's Middle East envoy, and his son Zach Witkoff, co-founder of the Trump-linked crypto firm World Liberty Financial, have engaged in parallel diplomatic and financial dealings with the United Arab Emirates and Pakistan. Steve Witkoff facilitated talks granting the UAE access to U.S. computer chips, while his son secured a $2 billion crypto investment from a UAE royal’s company. The younger Witkoff also pitched crypto and rare-earth tokenization schemes to Pakistani officials at the same time the Trump administration was negotiating diplomatic and aid agreements with Pakistan. World Liberty’s largest investors include Binance founder Changpeng Zhao, who is seeking a Trump pardon, and Justin Sun, who has been investigated by the SEC. Critics say the arrangement exemplifies pay-to-play diplomacy and foreign influence facilitated through digital assets.

title: Major U.S. Banks Explore Joint Stablecoin to Counter Trump Crypto Push
summary: The Wall Street Journal reported that JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, and other top banks are in early discussions to jointly launch a stablecoin in response to rising competition from cryptocurrencies—particularly Trump family-linked ventures like USD1. The discussions involve payment platforms like Zelle (Early Warning Services) and the Clearing House. The banks fear losing control over payments and deposits amid the Trump administration’s crypto deregulation, especially after the rise of USD1 as the fifth-largest stablecoin and the passage of the GENIUS Act. Industry sources see the stablecoin alliance as a potential defensive move to prevent Trump-affiliated crypto projects from dominating cross-border transactions.

title: Judge Orders Education Department to Reinstate 1,400 Fired Workers, Blocking Trump Cuts
summary: A federal judge issued a preliminary injunction ordering the Education Department to rehire nearly 1,400 workers laid off under President Trump’s reduction-in-force plan. The ruling halted Secretary Linda McMahon’s sweeping attempt to downsize and restructure the department, which had cut over 45% of its staff. Judge Myong J. Joun found that the Trump administration acted without congressional authorization, and that the cuts jeopardized the department’s legal obligations. The court cited widespread harm to schools, students, and civil rights enforcement, with major service breakdowns already reported in student aid processing and Office for Civil Rights investigations.

title: Supreme Court Allows Trump to Fire Independent Watchdogs, Challenging 90-Year-Old Precedent
summary: The Supreme Court ruled that President Trump may remove independent agency leaders without cause—at least temporarily—delivering a major blow to long-standing checks on executive power. The case involves Trump’s firings of Gwynne Wilcox from the National Labor Relations Board and Cathy A. Harris from the Merit Systems Protection Board, both Biden appointees. The unsigned order casts doubt on the 1935 Humphrey’s Executor precedent, which limits presidential control over independent commissions. In dissent, Justice Elena Kagan warned that the ruling undermines constitutional safeguards and allows Trump to 'bless' politically motivated removals. Legal experts say the decision could affect dozens of independent bodies, including the Federal Reserve, SEC, and Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Judge Blocks Trump Administration from Mass Termination of International Student Visas
summary: U.S. District Judge Jeffrey White issued a nationwide injunction halting the Trump administration's mass revocation of international student visas, calling the action 'arbitrary and capricious' and likely in excess of legal authority. The Department of Homeland Security had terminated the SEVIS records of at least 4,700 international students, citing their alleged participation in pro-Palestinian protests or support for Hamas. The judge's order bars the administration from arresting or deporting affected students while litigation proceeds, granting broad relief to protect academic continuity and due process rights. The ruling follows weeks of backlash over what advocates described as ideological targeting and retaliation against lawful visa holders.

title: Trump Confirms Attempted Deportation of Migrants to South Sudan in Violation of Court Order
summary: President Trump confirmed that a group of migrants from countries including Vietnam, Cuba, and Mexico were nearly deported to South Sudan, despite a federal court order prohibiting removal to third countries without notice. The administration had claimed the deportation destination was classified, but the flight landed in Djibouti en route to South Sudan. A federal judge condemned the action as a violation of judicial authority and ordered ICE to retain custody and provide legal access. The men’s exact location and conditions remain unclear, raising concerns about mistreatment. Trump denounced the ruling on social media, calling the migrants 'monsters' and demanding the Supreme Court override judicial constraints.

title: NYT: Foreign Crypto Investors Use Trump Memecoin Gala for Political Access
summary: A New York Times investigation revealed that hundreds of guests, including foreign crypto executives, attended President Trump’s exclusive $TRUMP memecoin dinner, viewing it as an opportunity to influence U.S. crypto regulation. Guests reportedly included Justin Sun (Tron), Kronos Research, and Hyperithm executives, many of whom lack U.S. regulatory approval. Attendees gained entry through a leaderboard-style contest, with the Trump family profiting via fees from over $320 million in trading volume. Donald Trump Jr. defended the arrangement, rejecting prior ethics pledges, and emphasizing a new willingness to profit during Trump’s second term. Critics, including Sen. Jeff Merkley, called the event 'the Mount Everest of corruption.' Promised VIP White House tours were later scrubbed from the event website amid ethical scrutiny.

title: Trump Promotes Fort Knox Conspiracies as Allies Profit Off Gold Panic
summary: President Trump has revived longstanding conspiracy theories about missing gold at Fort Knox, announcing plans to personally inspect the nation's bullion reserves despite reassurances from Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent that all gold is accounted for. Trump's baseless claims have been amplified by Elon Musk, Senator Rand Paul, Alex Jones, and Glenn Beck. These theories have been adopted by gold investment companies such as Birch Gold Group, which market precious metals as a safe haven amid fears of government instability. Birch and other firms have used Trump's rhetoric to promote gold IRAs, citing the potential collapse of the U.S. dollar if the gold is missing. Trump Jr., a paid Birch Gold spokesperson, called his father’s plans 'brilliant' and urged followers to 'prepare for the worst.'

title: Birch Gold Markets Trump Jr. Endorsement and Fort Knox Conspiracies to Sell Gold IRAs
summary: Birch Gold Group intensified its marketing efforts in early 2025 by leveraging unfounded conspiracy theories about missing gold at Fort Knox. The company published blog posts suggesting that concerns about the U.S. gold reserves have transitioned from fringe speculation to mainstream concern. These narratives were used to promote gold IRAs as a hedge against economic collapse, with Donald Trump Jr. endorsing the firm as 'his gold company.' Ads, podcasts, and Instagram promotions pitched precious metals as protection against a weakened dollar. A digitally altered image on Birch's site showed President Trump before a wall of gold bricks, while a 'Message from Don Jr.' claimed that revaluing U.S. gold reserves could yield major profits for investors holding gold through Birch.

title: Donald Trump Jr. Monetizes Fort Knox Panic and Crypto Hype in Gold IRA Push
summary: Donald Trump Jr. has used his media platforms and family political access to promote gold investment products amid rising conspiracy rhetoric about Fort Knox. Through a paid endorsement deal with Birch Gold Group, Trump Jr. encouraged followers to buy gold IRAs as protection from a possible economic crisis, citing his father's Fort Knox visit plans. He has also promoted the idea of revaluing U.S. gold reserves to market prices, claiming this would generate substantial profits for investors holding gold. This endorsement is part of a broader pattern in which Trump Jr. also backs cryptocurrency projects like World Liberty Financial and the $TRUMP coin, often blending political messaging with financial marketing.

title: Illegal Wiretap Rumors Rock Hegseth Investigation and Shake White House
summary: The Trump administration was blindsided by internal Pentagon claims that a leak investigation used to justify firing three top aides may have been based on an illegal NSA wiretap. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth had cited the leak of a top-secret plan to retake the Panama Canal when firing aides Dan Caldwell, Darin Selnick, and Colin Carroll in April. But White House officials later learned that Hegseth’s attorney, Tim Parlatore, allegedly suggested that NSA surveillance was used to obtain evidence—claims he later denied. The episode deepened distrust between the Pentagon and White House and raised concerns that the investigation was politically weaponized to eliminate staffers aligned with former chief of staff Joe Kasper. With no new evidence emerging, the probe has stalled and left Hegseth without a functioning chief of staff. Senate hearings are expected to further probe the legality of the investigation and Hegseth’s handling of internal dissent.

title: Trump's SEC Enables Insider Trading, Market Manipulation, and Memecoin Grift
summary: The Trump administration has dismantled key financial oversight mechanisms, enabling insider trading and self-dealing on an unprecedented scale. SEC enforcement staff have been slashed by nearly 20%, whistleblower protections have been gutted, and new rules under Chair Paul Atkins eliminate key audit trail disclosures for large investors. Trump’s April 2 tariff reversals triggered suspicious options activity and a sudden market surge. Charles Schwab reportedly gained $2.5 billion in one day, and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent was overheard tipping investors at a JPMorgan gathering ahead of Trump’s pivot. The $TRUMP memecoin has also attracted regulatory scrutiny after foreign investors were promised White House access in exchange for crypto purchases. Despite multiple Senate requests for investigations, the SEC has refused to act. Critics say the agency now serves as a shield for Trump-aligned profiteers, creating a lawless financial landscape and unprecedented potential for abuse.

title: NPR Sues Trump Over Defunding Order, Citing First Amendment Retaliation
summary: National Public Radio filed a lawsuit against the Trump administration over an executive order that ended federal funding for public media. The suit alleges the move violates both the First Amendment and the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, which prohibits the government from exerting control over the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. NPR, joined by several local affiliates, described the order as 'textbook retaliation' for critical coverage of the administration and an unconstitutional attempt to silence independent journalism. The executive order stated that NPR and PBS failed to provide 'a fair or unbiased portrayal of current events.' Critics say the order is part of a broader pattern of state media suppression. PBS and CPB have said they will fight the order, which threatens $535 million in funding annually to more than 1,500 public broadcasting stations.

title: Trump Media Raises $2.5 Billion to Buy Bitcoin, Citing 'Financial Freedom'
summary: Trump Media & Technology Group, parent company of Truth Social and majority-owned by President Trump, announced a plan to raise $2.5 billion to purchase Bitcoin, marking a dramatic pivot from social media to crypto investment. The company said it would raise $1.5 billion by selling 58 million shares and another $1 billion via convertible bonds. CEO Devin Nunes called Bitcoin an 'apex instrument of financial freedom.' The deal comes amid declining revenues at Truth Social, which posted a $32 million loss last quarter, and follows Trump's broader turn to cryptocurrency as a vehicle for enrichment. The firm’s largest shareholder is Trump himself, with his shares held in trust by Donald Trump Jr., who also sits on the board. The fundraising follows Trump’s crypto-themed donor dinner and aligns with a broader Trump family push into crypto ventures, including $TRUMP memecoin, World Liberty Financial, and the upcoming IPO of American Bitcoin, co-founded by Eric Trump.

title: Trump Media Plans Politicized Bitcoin ETF Lineup With Foreign Partners
summary: Trump Media & Technology Group announced plans to launch a series of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) backed by Bitcoin and companies aligned with Trump's 'America First' platform. The initiative is a joint venture with Crypto.com, a Singapore-based crypto exchange; Yorkville Advisors, a New Jersey investment firm; and Anchorage Digital, a crypto bank. The ETF strategy marks a major shift in Trump Media’s business model and reflects President Trump’s full embrace of cryptocurrency as both policy and profit mechanism. Critics warn that the plan blurs the line between political branding and financial products, with potential for regulatory capture and selective enforcement. The ETFs would provide international and domestic investors with access to portfolios aligned with the administration’s favored industries and ideology, raising new questions about conflicts of interest and the monetization of political identity.

title: Trump Fires Top U.S. Copyright Official After She Refuses to Endorse Musk AI Proposal
summary: President Trump fired Shira Perlmutter, the nation’s top copyright official, just one day after she declined to support Elon Musk’s efforts to allow AI systems to mine copyrighted content without restriction. Perlmutter had authored a report outlining legal concerns with unlicensed use of creative works to train AI, prompting backlash from Musk-aligned figures. Her dismissal followed the removal of Librarian of Congress Carla Hayden, who had appointed Perlmutter to the role. Under federal law, the Register of Copyrights is appointed by and accountable to the Librarian of Congress—not the president. Lawmakers including Rep. Joe Morelle denounced the firings as unconstitutional and part of a broader power grab aimed at silencing regulatory resistance to Musk’s AI agenda. Observers warn the firings could destabilize a trillion-dollar industry and erode congressional control over copyright policy.

title: Musk and McHenry Push to Redefine Copyright Law for AI Training
summary: Elon Musk and Rep. Patrick McHenry have initiated a campaign to overhaul U.S. copyright laws, aiming to facilitate the use of copyrighted materials in AI training without traditional licensing. This movement gained momentum following the U.S. Copyright Office's release of a report questioning the applicability of 'fair use' in the context of AI training. Shortly after the report's publication, President Trump dismissed both Librarian of Congress Carla Hayden and Register of Copyrights Shira Perlmutter, actions perceived as politically motivated to align copyright policy with pro-AI industry interests. Critics argue that these dismissals undermine the independence of the Copyright Office and could lead to unchecked use of creative works by AI developers. The situation has sparked bipartisan concern over the balance between technological advancement and the protection of intellectual property rights.

title: Trump Media Plans $3 Billion Crypto Raise as Trump Sons and Allies Promote Investment
summary: Trump Media & Technology Group plans to raise $3 billion to fund cryptocurrency purchases, expanding its pivot from social media to financial speculation. The company aims to raise $2 billion in equity and another $1 billion through convertible debt. The capital raise coincides with a major crypto gathering in Las Vegas, where Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, VP JD Vance, and crypto czar David Sacks are all scheduled to speak. Trump Media, which controls Truth Social, is now pursuing a playbook similar to that of MicroStrategy, using its stock to acquire large bitcoin reserves. The offering follows weeks of political messaging positioning the Trump administration as the most crypto-friendly in U.S. history. Trump’s sons now control the revocable trust holding the president’s majority stake in the company, and related entities like World Liberty Financial and American Bitcoin are pursuing parallel deals. The offering has raised red flags about foreign influence, conflicts of interest, and regulatory evasion, especially given the family’s repeated use of financial products as vehicles for political access.

title: Trump Family Hosts Vegas Crypto Summit to Court Investors and Promote Policy
summary: In late May 2025, Trump Media and allied crypto firms hosted a private crypto summit in Las Vegas, drawing top investors and administration officials. Speakers included Vice President JD Vance, Trump sons Donald Jr. and Eric, and Trump’s 'crypto czar' David Sacks. The event coincided with Trump Media’s $3 billion capital raise for cryptocurrency investments and followed a recent memecoin gala dinner that offered access to the president in exchange for holdings in $TRUMP. Attendees described the event as blending policy signaling with investment opportunity, as officials touted Trump’s vow to make the U.S. 'the crypto capital of the world.' The summit further blurred the lines between political power and private enrichment, while creating a pipeline for foreign and domestic financiers to align their holdings with favorable regulatory treatment. Critics warn that this evolving structure effectively merges U.S. digital asset policy with the personal business strategy of the Trump family.

title: DOGE Guts FOIA Offices, Silencing Oversight and Undermining Transparency
summary: The Trump administration has systematically dismantled FOIA (Freedom of Information Act) offices across multiple federal agencies, part of a broader effort to suppress public access to government records. According to a report by the Revolving Door Project, the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), led by Elon Musk, has presided over sweeping layoffs and staffing freezes in FOIA units, making it nearly impossible for journalists, watchdogs, or citizens to obtain internal agency records. Civil servants report that retaliation, demotions, and legal intimidation have chilled internal dissent and whistleblowing. Regulators now fear that sharing sensitive information—even anonymously—could result in firing or legal sanction. The result is a blackout on accountability, as FOIA backlogs swell and disclosure pipelines collapse. Legal scholars warn that the strategy effectively defangs one of the last remaining tools for external oversight of federal agencies.

title: Private Firms Reap Billions from Trump Deportation Contracts, El Salvador Prisons
summary: A Wall Street Journal investigation revealed that the Trump administration has supercharged a privatized deportation industry, awarding over $13 billion in contracts in the past decade and increasing removals-related spending by 50% since last year. The report traces the journey of Andry Blanco Bonilla, a Venezuelan asylum seeker with no criminal record, who was arrested by ICE after an officer flagged his tattoos. He was detained at multiple private facilities—including Prairieland and Bluebonnet—operated by LaSalle Corrections and Management and Training Corp, which together have received hundreds of millions in federal funds. Blanco was ultimately deported to El Salvador and imprisoned at the CECOT mega-prison under a U.S. contract worth $6 million annually. The Journal notes that companies profit at nearly every step of the process: transportation, detention, medical care, and international incarceration. Critics warn the system incentivizes overreach and racial profiling, with little transparency and no due process for many deportees.

title: U.S. Outsources Deportations to El Salvador's CECOT Prison Amid Crypto Diplomacy
summary: The Trump administration has outsourced mass deportations to El Salvador's controversial CECOT mega-prison, paying $6 million annually to house migrants with little or no criminal history under contracts that lack transparency. According to a Wall Street Journal investigation, detainees like Venezuelan asylum seeker Andry Blanco Bonilla were arrested without due process and transferred from U.S. private detention centers to El Salvador on mass flights. The agreement aligns with broader U.S. efforts to incentivize immigration enforcement cooperation from the Bukele government, which has also become a preferred partner in Trump’s global crypto agenda. El Salvador has hosted American Bitcoin-linked ventures, stablecoin firms like Tether, and digital asset summits featuring Trump officials. Watchdogs warn that the financial ties between Trump allies, El Salvador’s crypto infrastructure, and ICE deportation operations signal a convergence of digital asset diplomacy and human rights violations.

title: Commerce Secretary Lutnick's Tether Ties Raise Conflict of Interest Concerns
summary: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick is facing scrutiny over his longstanding ties to the cryptocurrency firm Tether, which relocated to El Salvador and manages more than $134 billion in assets. As the former CEO of Cantor Fitzgerald, Lutnick retains a financial interest in the firm, which owns a 5% stake in Tether and manages a substantial portion of its reserves. Under Lutnick’s leadership, the Commerce Department has praised El Salvador as a crypto 'model partner' while simultaneously overseeing immigration agreements and economic diplomacy. Critics warn that these overlapping interests pose ethical risks, especially after Tether funneled $775 million into Rumble, a pro-Trump video platform. Watchdogs say Lutnick’s dual role as a crypto investor and public official undermines public trust and raises serious questions about the administration’s approach to financial regulation.

title: El Salvador's Bukele Partners with Trump on Deportations Amid Crypto Collaborations
summary: President Nayib Bukele of El Salvador has become a central figure in the Trump administration's mass deportation strategy, accepting hundreds of deportees under controversial contracts tied to the CECOT mega-prison. Among them are 238 Venezuelans and 23 Salvadorans accused of gang ties, many without due process. The U.S. is paying El Salvador $6 million to incarcerate these migrants. Bukele's government has also aligned with Trump’s crypto agenda, welcoming firms like Tether and hosting U.S.-backed crypto ventures. Human rights groups have raised alarm about Bukele's tactics, including indefinite detentions and suppression of press coverage. Despite this, the administration continues to frame El Salvador as a model partner—both for digital asset innovation and outsourced immigration enforcement.

title: Trump and Allies Fuel Surge in Violent Threats Against U.S. Judges
summary: Violent threats against U.S. federal judges have risen by more than 300% over the past year, according to a report by the Global Project Against Hate and Extremism (GPAHE). The increase has been driven in part by rhetoric from President Trump, Elon Musk, and other Trump administration officials targeting judges who have ruled against them. In one case, Trump called Judge James Boasberg a 'radical left lunatic' who 'should be IMPEACHED!!!' after Boasberg ordered the administration to halt deportation flights. Elon Musk called similar rulings a 'judicial coup' and demanded that judges be removed. The report documents threats and slurs against judges on platforms including Truth Social, TikTok, Gab, 4chan, and Rumble. In March 2025 alone, over 9,000 threats were posted to Truth Social. Swatting attacks and real-world threats have followed—including a bomb threat against Judge John Coughenour. Watchdogs warn that normalization of violent speech by public officials is creating a climate of intimidation that undermines judicial independence.

title: DOGE Quietly Expands Post-Musk as Federal Surveillance and Data Merging Continue
summary: Despite Elon Musk's public announcement that he would step back from his role in government, the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) continues to operate and has become functionally indistinguishable from the rest of the Trump administration. According to WIRED, DOGE is now embedded across federal agencies, quietly analyzing merged datasets originally meant to remain siloed. Its operatives are using Musk’s xAI Grok model to process sensitive federal data, raising serious privacy and conflict-of-interest concerns. Former Musk aides remain in key posts, and new DOGE initiatives include surveillance of immigrants, voter fraud allegations, and AI-led rule rewrites. Project 2025 architect Russell Vought has taken over the cost-cutting mantle, signaling that DOGE's agenda will continue by other means. Observers warn that DOGE has shifted from shock-force tactics to systemic infiltration, making oversight more difficult as its actions grow quieter but no less consequential.

title: Musk's xAI Grok Model Taps Federal Datasets Under DOGE Oversight
summary: Elon Musk's AI company xAI is now using its Grok chatbot to process and analyze sensitive U.S. government data under the oversight of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE). According to WIRED, Grok is being fed merged datasets from across federal agencies, originally not intended to be combined, to generate insights for immigration surveillance, voter fraud claims, and regulatory enforcement. The training of Grok on these datasets raises profound privacy concerns, especially given Musk's commercial interests in AI and his ongoing control of xAI. Despite Musk's public statements about stepping back from DOGE, his AI products are embedded within government workflows and actively influencing policy implementation. Watchdogs warn that this convergence of public data and private algorithms represents a form of soft privatization of federal intelligence functions, with little transparency or congressional oversight.

title: Project 2025 Architect Russell Vought Transitions DOGE Powers Into OMB
summary: Following Elon Musk's partial withdrawal from DOGE, former Trump budget director Russell Vought has assumed primary responsibility for operationalizing the agency’s agenda through the White House Office of Management and Budget. As the chief architect of Project 2025, Vought told Fox Business that his mission is to 'make those savings permanent' using all available executive tools. While DOGE drew public scrutiny for its brash tactics, OMB under Vought has taken a quieter approach—systematically embedding data analytics, surveillance, and cost-cutting mechanisms across the federal government. According to WIRED, Vought's plan includes institutionalizing DOGE's priorities through regulatory reforms, budgetary levers, and personnel management—effectively making the agency redundant by absorbing its functions into the broader state apparatus. Critics warn that this institutional drift gives cover for ongoing structural erosion of transparency, oversight, and social protections.

title: Trump Crypto Ventures Draw Firestorm of Ethics and National Security Warnings
summary: A Guardian investigation has exposed a web of financial and political entanglements surrounding Donald Trump’s cryptocurrency ventures, including direct payments for access, deregulation, and foreign influence. According to the report, buyers spent $148 million in $TRUMP memecoin to attend a May 22 dinner at Trump’s Virginia golf club, with top investors attending a private reception. Justin Sun, the coin’s top buyer and lead investor in World Liberty Financial, has been under SEC investigation for market manipulation and money laundering. That investigation was paused after Trump appointees took over the agency. WLF is also facilitating a $2 billion investment in Binance through a UAE fund using the Trump-branded stablecoin USD1. Critics have called this a 'roadmap for corruption,' citing the SEC’s retreat from enforcement, national security risks, and the administration’s ties to opaque foreign-backed crypto flows. Democrats introduced the End Crypto Corruption Act to bar presidents from profiting from personal financial products while in office.

title: Vietnam Fast-Tracks Trump Golf Complex Amid Tariff Threats and Legal Shortcuts
summary: Vietnamese officials bypassed multiple legal and regulatory steps to accelerate approval of a $1.5 billion Trump Organization golf and real estate complex outside Hanoi, citing 'special attention from the Trump administration.' A New York Times investigation revealed that the development was greenlit in just over three months—far faster than the usual multi-year review process—and ahead of a meeting between U.S. and Vietnamese trade negotiators. President Trump had recently imposed steep tariffs on Vietnamese exports, then paused them during diplomacy that overlapped with Eric Trump’s groundbreaking trip. Residents were pressured into signing land transfer documents under duress, with police presence and minimal compensation for ancestral farmland and cemeteries. The project’s backers used the development as a political bargaining chip to curry favor with the White House, while Trump continues to profit personally from the brand via revocable trust. Legal scholars warn this blurs the line between trade policy and personal enrichment, with long-term risks for U.S. credibility abroad.

title: Trump Administration Admits First Amendment Violation After Pulling LGBTQ-Inclusive Medical Research
summary: A government lawyer representing the Trump administration admitted in federal court that removing two Harvard Medical School professors’ research from a federal website constituted unconstitutional viewpoint discrimination. The lawsuit, brought by Professors Celeste Royce and Gordon Schiff, challenged the sudden deletion of their peer-reviewed articles from the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality’s Patient Safety Network. The articles had included references to transgender and LGBTQ individuals in medically relevant contexts. Their removal followed a January 2025 executive order banning 'gender ideology' and a directive from the Office of Personnel Management to scrub public-facing content. U.S. District Judge Leo Sorokin sharply criticized the government’s rationale and questioned its legality. The administration cited technical barriers to restoring the content and admitted that the federal database itself is being shut down. The ACLU, representing the plaintiffs, is seeking an injunction against future censorship. The case highlights the growing use of executive authority to suppress academic and scientific speech.

title: Trump Family Has Netted Over $2 Billion Since Return to Office, NYT Reports
summary: A New York Times analysis found that the Trump family has received more than $2 billion in direct business revenue since Donald Trump returned to the presidency, with financial gains flowing from real estate, cryptocurrency, and political access schemes. The family’s ventures include the $TRUMP memecoin, which generated at least $174 million from investors seeking White House access; a $2 billion investment from the UAE into the Trump-linked crypto firm World Liberty Financial; and foreign-funded real estate projects in Qatar, the UAE, Oman, and Serbia. These include a $5.5 billion golf resort in Doha and a $1 billion Trump Tower deal in Dubai. Qatar is also reportedly gifting Trump a $400 million presidential jet, later to be used for his library. Meanwhile, Eric Trump and Donald Jr. are launching a $500,000-per-seat private club for donors and lobbyists in D.C. The White House insists the president is not involved, but financial disclosures show Trump remains a beneficiary of nearly all these ventures.

title: Supreme Court Temporarily Blocks Order Requiring DOGE to Disclose Internal Records
summary: Chief Justice John Roberts issued an administrative stay temporarily blocking a lower court’s order that would have forced the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) to release internal records to Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW). The watchdog group filed a FOIA lawsuit after the Trump administration claimed DOGE was a presidential advisory body—not a federal agency—and therefore exempt from disclosure laws. A federal judge disagreed, ruling that DOGE appeared to wield substantial governmental authority and must produce communications, financial disclosures, and organizational charts. CREW argued that exempting DOGE from FOIA would allow the president to create powerful but opaque executive entities beyond the reach of public scrutiny. The Supreme Court stay gives justices more time to weigh the constitutional issues. The case coincides with a broader legal battle over DOGE’s access to Social Security data and its role in disbanding independent agencies.

title: ICE Arrests Immigrants at Courthouses Nationwide in Fast-Track Deportation Sweep
summary: The Trump administration has launched a new initiative directing Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers to arrest immigrants immediately after their court cases are dismissed or a deportation order is issued. According to internal documents obtained by the Washington Post, the arrests are part of an effort to bypass full judicial review and move immigrants into expedited removal — a process that offers minimal legal protections. Federal agents arrested individuals outside courthouses in more than 20 states, including Arizona, Virginia, Illinois, and Washington. Witnesses described plainclothes and masked officers detaining people as they left hearings, sometimes with family members present. The policy has shocked immigration attorneys, who say it punishes individuals for complying with the legal process. Critics argue it undermines judicial independence, chills courtroom participation, and exposes asylum seekers to fatal danger. Lawsuits challenging the policy are underway, and human rights groups warn that it may violate constitutional guarantees to due process.

title: Federal Judge Strikes Down Trump Executive Order Targeting Law Firm Jenner & Block
summary: A federal judge struck down an executive order issued by President Trump that targeted the prominent law firm Jenner & Block, ruling it a violation of the First Amendment. The ruling by Judge John Bates found that the order unlawfully retaliated against the firm for its past representation of politically disfavored clients and its former employment of Andrew Weissmann, who served on Robert Mueller’s team during the Russia investigation. The order had sought to strip the firm’s security clearances, block access to federal buildings, and prompt agencies to cut ties with its clients. Bates ruled the order was 'doubly violative' of the Constitution by attempting both to punish legal advocacy and chill future representation. This is the latest in a string of legal defeats for the administration’s campaign against politically unaffiliated law firms, following earlier rulings in favor of Perkins Coie and WilmerHale.

title: PBS Censors Trump Criticism in Spiegelman Documentary Amid Defunding Pressure
summary: Producers of the PBS series 'American Masters' removed a scene critical of President Trump from an upcoming documentary about graphic novelist Art Spiegelman just two weeks before its scheduled national broadcast. The cut scene featured a cartoon Spiegelman created after Trump’s 2016 election, which depicted fly-covered feces on Trump’s head. WNET, PBS’s largest affiliate, claimed the imagery violated 'taste' standards, but filmmakers believe the decision was driven by political fear following a congressional hearing where Republicans accused public media of liberal bias. The censorship came shortly after Trump signed an executive order directing the Corporation for Public Broadcasting to cut all federal funds to NPR and PBS. The filmmakers—including Spiegelman himself—called the cut 'tragic and appalling' and warned that public media’s retreat from controversial topics would chill artistic expression. The uncut version of the film had previously aired at festivals and on streaming platforms.

title: Strive Asset Management Launches Trump-Linked Bitcoin Treasury Scheme
summary: A new Financial Times report reveals that Strive Asset Management, a firm co-founded by Trump surrogate Vivek Ramaswamy and backed by investors including Vice President JD Vance and Peter Thiel, is merging with a Nasdaq-listed shell company to form a 'Bitcoin Treasury Company.' The structure is designed to mimic MicroStrategy by accumulating bitcoin and offering tax-sheltered equity in return. Strive’s deal partners include Asset Entities, a meme finance Discord platform founded by a 21-year-old TikToker with no formal investment background. The firm plans to encourage public bitcoin contributions in exchange for ownership stakes, leveraging a merger structure under Section 351 of the U.S. tax code. Strive’s backers have ties to Trump’s other crypto ventures including Twenty One Capital and American Bitcoin. Financial analysts warn that the structure may enable crypto influence-peddling and soft deregulation through pro-Trump investment vehicles.

title: Federal Judge Rules Visa Revocation of Harvard Scientist Was Unlawful
summary: A federal judge ruled that the Trump administration had no legal basis to revoke the J-1 visa of Kseniia Petrova, a Russian biologist conducting frog embryo research at Harvard Medical School. Petrova was detained in February 2025 at Boston Logan Airport after failing to declare frog embryos she had picked up from a French lab for academic study. Although no safety threat was posed, immigration officials revoked her visa and placed her in ICE custody, citing smuggling. Petrova testified she feared deportation to Russia due to her antiwar activism. U.S. District Judge Christina Reiss ordered her release on bail, stating that immigration officers acted without proper legal authority. The Trump administration responded by filing criminal charges against Petrova for alleged smuggling—despite experts noting such infractions typically result in minor civil fines. The case has alarmed the scientific community, highlighting a broader crackdown on international researchers and erosion of academic freedom under immigration pretexts.

title: Trump Administration Deploys Criminal Agents to Target Migrant Children in ‘Wellness Checks’
summary: The New York Times reports that Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) agents have been visiting homes, schools, libraries, and shelters to conduct unannounced 'wellness checks' on unaccompanied migrant children. While framed as protective, these visits are being conducted not by social workers but by ICE agents trained in criminal enforcement. The checks have led to the arrest and detention of undocumented caregivers and the photographing of homes, raising fears of renewed family separations and child removals. In Los Angeles, schools denied agents access to students. Advocates argue the initiative is being used to identify, interrogate, and deport families through their children, often without legal counsel. Internal documents reveal that the Office of Refugee Resettlement has hired deportation specialists, and Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. confirmed that his agency is sharing data with DHS to locate and interview the estimated 300,000 'missing' minors. The program has been widely condemned by immigration attorneys as a political escalation cloaked in child protection.

title: Judge Strikes Down Trump Executive Order Targeting WilmerHale
summary: A federal judge permanently blocked a Trump executive order targeting the elite law firm WilmerHale, which had previously employed former special counsel Robert Mueller. U.S. District Judge Richard Leon ruled that the order was an unconstitutional attack on lawyers' independence, barring WilmerHale attorneys from entering federal buildings, working with federal clients, or maintaining security clearances. The Trump administration justified the order by accusing Mueller and the firm of 'upending the democratic process.' Leon dismissed that rationale, calling the order a direct threat to an 'independent bar willing to tackle unpopular cases.' This is the third such order struck down by federal courts, following earlier rulings protecting Jenner & Block and Perkins Coie. Other firms have settled with the White House by agreeing to provide pro bono work to administration-approved causes. Critics warn the strategy resembles a modern bill of attainder, using federal power to punish disfavored law firms for past legal work.

title: Judge Blocks Trump Administration from Banning Harvard's Foreign Students — For Now
summary: A federal judge in Boston announced she would temporarily block the Trump administration's attempt to bar Harvard University from enrolling international students. The decision is part of an escalating legal and political confrontation between the university and the White House. President Trump has already stripped Harvard of billions in federal funding, referred to its faculty as 'birdbrains,' and stated that international students should be capped at 15% to make more space for Americans — undercutting his own administration's argument that merit alone should guide admissions. The administration had given Harvard 30 days to justify why it should be allowed to enroll foreign students at all. Internal filings revealed widespread fear among Harvard's international student body, with many seeking to transfer. White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt denounced the ruling and claimed the judge had 'overreached.' Student rallies, commencement protests, and faculty solidarity actions continue as the court fight proceeds.

title: Trump Administration to Aggressively Revoke Visas for Chinese Students
summary: Secretary of State Marco Rubio announced that the U.S. will begin 'aggressively' revoking visas of Chinese students, especially those with connections to the Chinese Communist Party or studying in critical fields. The State Department will also revise visa criteria to enhance scrutiny of all future applications from China and Hong Kong. This policy shift has raised alarms among educational institutions and international students, with critics likening it to a modern-day Chinese Exclusion Act. Chinese students constitute a significant portion of the international student population in the U.S., and this move is expected to have substantial implications for universities and U.S.-China relations.

title: Musk Tried to Block OpenAI’s Gulf Deal Without xAI Involvement, Sources Say
summary: According to a Wall Street Journal investigation, Elon Musk privately warned U.A.E. officials that President Trump would not approve their multibillion-dollar AI data center deal with OpenAI unless Musk’s startup, xAI, was included. The call was placed to leaders at G42, a company controlled by the U.A.E. president’s brother. After learning Sam Altman would be joining Trump on his Gulf tour to finalize the deal, Musk joined the trip himself and pressured U.S. officials. The White House ultimately approved the OpenAI-led deal, dubbed Stargate U.A.E., despite Musk’s objections. The article documents months of geopolitical jockeying, as the U.A.E. sought access to restricted AI chips, invested in Trump-affiliated projects, and secured exceptions to U.S. export rules. Musk’s own companies benefited from parallel deals in the region, including a Boring Company tunnel project in Dubai and inclusion in the chip allocation shortlist. Critics say Musk’s attempt to derail the OpenAI project reveals the blurred lines between his business empire, federal power, and foreign policy.

title: Federal Court Strikes Down Trump's Global Tariffs as Unconstitutional
summary: The U.S. Court of International Trade ruled that President Trump lacked legal authority to impose sweeping tariffs on nearly all U.S. trading partners under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). The court found that Trump’s justification — a national emergency rooted in the U.S. trade deficit — failed to meet the law's definition of an 'unusual and extraordinary threat.' The decision voided tariffs imposed on Canada, Mexico, China, and others that had sparked global retaliation and stock market turmoil. Judges warned that allowing such 'unbounded tariff power' would represent an unconstitutional delegation of authority from Congress to the executive. The ruling follows lawsuits from 13 states and several small businesses. Trump administration lawyers vowed to appeal. Critics hailed the ruling as a major win for constitutional checks and balances, but warned the administration could seek to reimpose similar duties using alternative legal justifications, such as Section 301 of the Trade Act. Market indexes rose sharply on news of the ruling.

title: Trump Media Raises $2.5B to Become a Bitcoin Treasury Platform
summary: Trump Media and Technology Group (TMTG), the parent company of Truth Social, has raised $2.5 billion to purchase bitcoin and convert itself into a public bitcoin treasury company. The plan mirrors MicroStrategy’s strategy, positioning TMTG as a crypto stock proxy. Initially denying the move, TMTG reversed course and confirmed it would sell $1.5 billion in equity and take on $1 billion in debt to amass crypto holdings. CEO Devin Nunes declared bitcoin a ‘cornerstone asset’ aligned with ‘America First’ principles. The move places TMTG alongside Trump family ventures including American Bitcoin (Eric Trump), World Liberty Financial (Donald Trump Jr.), and Truth.Fi (Melania Trump). All these ventures are tied to cryptocurrency accumulation, access sales, and political influence. Critics argue the strategy weaponizes Trump’s brand to draw capital while offloading financial risk onto public investors. Regulatory analysts warn that the proliferation of Trump-linked bitcoin stocks may distort policy and asset markets by creating pseudo-governmental vehicles for crypto speculation.

title: Eric Trump's American Bitcoin to Go Public via Merger
summary: American Bitcoin, a cryptocurrency mining firm co-founded by Eric Trump and Donald Trump Jr., announced plans to go public through an all-stock merger with Gryphon Digital Mining. The Trump brothers, along with crypto miner Hut 8, will retain 98% ownership of the new entity, which aims to become a leading investment platform for accumulating Bitcoin. Eric Trump will serve as Chief Strategy Officer. Critics raise ethical concerns over potential conflicts of interest, as the venture aligns with President Trump's pro-crypto policies, including deregulation efforts that benefit such enterprises.

title: Brandon Lutnick's $3B Bitcoin Venture Raises Conflict Concerns
summary: Brandon Lutnick, son of U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, is leading a $3 billion Bitcoin investment initiative through Cantor Equity Partners. The venture, backed by SoftBank and stablecoin operator Tether, aims to establish a significant Bitcoin treasury. The involvement of the Commerce Secretary's son in such a substantial cryptocurrency endeavor raises questions about potential conflicts of interest, especially given the Trump administration's favorable stance towards crypto regulations, which could benefit the venture.

title: Trump Administration Expands Palantir Contracts to Build Master Database of Americans' Personal Data
summary: The Trump administration has awarded Palantir over $113 million in federal contracts since January 2025 to implement its Foundry data platform across at least four federal agencies, creating technological infrastructure for merging sensitive personal information on Americans. The effort, driven by DOGE, includes bank account numbers, student debt, medical claims, and disability status from agencies including DHS, HHS, IRS, and Social Security Administration. Palantir employees have expressed concerns about reputational damage and security risks, with 13 former employees signing a letter urging the company to cease Trump administration work. The initiative follows Trump's March executive order calling for data sharing across agencies, raising concerns about potential surveillance and targeting of immigrants and political critics.

title: Trump Withdraws NASA Nomination of Musk Associate Jared Isaacman, Demands 'Complete Alignment' with America First Agenda
summary: President Trump withdrew billionaire Jared Isaacman's nomination to lead NASA just before a scheduled Senate confirmation vote, stating the next NASA leader must be in 'complete alignment with President Trump's America First agenda.' Isaacman, who conducted two private SpaceX flights and described himself as a 'political hypermoderate,' had drawn scrutiny for his ties to Elon Musk and SpaceX. The withdrawal coincides with proposed severe budget cuts to NASA—from $25 billion to $18.8 billion—and a 32% workforce reduction. Isaacman had previously opposed reducing NASA's science budget by 50% and sold his SpaceX stock to avoid conflicts of interest.

title: DOJ Investigates Harvard Law Review Using White House 'Cooperating Witness' in Escalation of Harvard Campaign
summary: The Justice Department opened a civil rights investigation into Harvard Law Review, claiming discrimination against white men and evidence destruction, while revealing it has a 'cooperating witness' now working in the White House under Stephen Miller. Daniel Wasserman, a Harvard Law School student who downloaded tens of thousands of Law Review documents and leaked them to conservative media, was hired by the White House on April 25—the same day discrimination allegations first surfaced. The DOJ threatened Harvard with criminal charges and demanded the Law Review retract Wasserman's disciplinary reprimand before his graduation. Fearing federal retaliation, Law Review officials complied with DOJ demands and destroyed the reprimand. The episode exemplifies the administration's strategy of using federal investigatory powers to advance its political agenda through 'speed and shock value.'

title: DOGE Operations Escalate Across Federal Agencies Despite Musk's Claimed Departure
summary: Despite public claims of stepping back, Elon Musk remains actively involved in DOGE operations, with Trump stating 'Elon's really not leaving' during a joint press conference where Musk wore DOGE-branded clothing. Federal workers from six agencies report intensified DOGE activities, including urgent contract cancellations, new approval processes, and unspecified interviews with technical staff. Core DOGE team members Luke Farritor, Gavin Kliger, Edward Coristine, and Sam Corcos continue meeting with Treasury, OMB, and FBI. At OPM, tech contractors received termination letters explicitly crediting DOGE with their dismissal. Trump confirmed that 'many contracts are being looked at' and presented Musk with a golden key during the ceremony, while agencies implement new bureaucratic hurdles like HHS's 'Departmental Efficiency Review' process.

title: Trump Family Feuds Over 'Official' Crypto Wallet as Multiple Ventures Compete for Brand Control
summary: A public dispute erupted between Trump family crypto ventures over which entity can use the Trump brand for crypto wallets. Fight Fight Fight LLC, which manages the $TRUMP memecoin, announced an 'official $TRUMP wallet' partnership with Magic Eden, prompting Eric Trump and Donald Trump Jr. to publicly repudiate the project as unauthorized. The Trump sons claimed only World Liberty Financial, their crypto company, would launch the legitimate Trump family wallet. This marks the second intra-family crypto conflict in two weeks, following Trump Media's $2.5 billion bitcoin treasury announcement that competes with Eric and Donald Jr.'s American Bitcoin mining firm. The disputes highlight the 'inscrutability' of relationships between Trump Organization, Trump Media, World Liberty Financial, American Bitcoin, and Fight Fight Fight as the family expands into nearly every crypto sector amid ongoing conflicts of interest concerns.

title: Trump and Musk Relationship Melts Down in Public Social Media Feud
summary: A spectacular public feud erupted between President Trump and Elon Musk just days after Trump celebrated Musk with an Oval Office farewell and ceremonial White House key. The conflict began over Trump's domestic policy bill, with Musk posting 'Without me, Trump would have lost the election. Such ingratitude.' Trump responded by threatening to eliminate Musk's government subsidies and contracts, calling it the 'easiest way to save money in our Budget.' Musk escalated dramatically by alleging '@realDonaldTrump is in the Epstein files. That is the real reason they have not been made public.' The hours-long social media battle played out across Truth Social and X, with Musk unfollowing Trump allies like Charlie Kirk and Stephen Miller. The breakdown raises questions about the future of Tesla and SpaceX government contracts and whether Musk's companies will face retaliation.

title: US Could Default on Debt as Soon as July Due to Congressional Inaction on Debt Ceiling
summary: The Bipartisan Policy Center warned that the federal government could default on its debt between mid-July and early October 2025, as Congress has failed to address the debt ceiling suspension that expired in early 2025. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen implemented 'extraordinary measures' in January after the government reached the new limit. The looming X-Date creates pressure on Republicans' ambitious reconciliation plans to extend Trump's tax cuts and handle the debt ceiling without Democratic support. Internal GOP divisions could complicate these plans, potentially forcing the administration to negotiate with Democrats or risk the first-ever U.S. debt default. The debt ceiling caps how much the Treasury can borrow to pay existing obligations, and failure to raise it would threaten the full faith and credit of the United States.

title: Trump Administration Holds Eight Deportees in Legal Limbo at U.S. Military Base in Djibouti
summary: Eight men convicted of serious crimes remain stranded at Camp Lemonnier, a U.S. military base in Djibouti, after the Trump administration attempted to deport them to South Sudan in violation of a federal court order requiring 15 days' notice and meaningful opportunity to contest deportation. Federal Judge Brian Murphy found DHS gave the men less than 24 hours' notice before the May 20 deportation flight, violating due process rights. The men—from Vietnam, South Korea, Mexico, Laos, Cuba, Myanmar, and South Sudan—were initially told they were going to South Africa, then South Sudan hours before departure. Eleven ICE officers now guard the detainees in 12-hour shifts in an air-conditioned shipping container, with the men wearing ankle shackles and allowed five-minute family calls every three days. The administration has appealed to the Supreme Court while blaming the judge for 'deteriorating conditions' rather than returning the men to U.S. detention centers.

title: Trump Administration Systematically Dismantles Expert Class Across Federal Government
summary: The Trump administration has eviscerated expertise across federal agencies, leaving National Security Council offices half-vacant and dismantling 14 Pentagon advisory boards dealing with nuclear strategy and cybersecurity threats. DOGE teams shut down the Wilson Center think tank, including its Cold War archives and Russia expertise at a time of superpower conflict. The National Weather Service lost so many experts it had to rehire them, while CDC vaccine advisory boards were bypassed when RFK Jr. made decisions without expert consultation. Scientists at EPA have removed 'climate' and 'green energy' from project documents out of self-protection. The National Intelligence Council leadership was removed after refusing to rewrite findings that contradicted Trump's Venezuela deportation justifications. The systematic purge extends beyond normal presidential transitions, with comparisons to China's cultural revolution where 'the only good ideas are the ones that flow from the leader.' Former NSA adviser H.R. McMaster warned the approach eliminates 'deliberative process' on critical issues like tariffs.

title: Trump Issues Proclamation to Bar Harvard's International Students, Prompting Emergency Court Block
summary: After a federal judge blocked DHS's attempt to strip Harvard of its ability to enroll international students, President Trump issued a new presidential proclamation barring those students from entering the U.S. for six months. The proclamation sought to override the earlier ruling and instructed the State Department to consider revoking visas already issued to current students. Harvard swiftly filed an amended lawsuit and won a temporary restraining order blocking the proclamation. The administration's ongoing pressure campaign—including the freezing of $2.2 billion in research funds, tax status threats, and retaliatory visa processing delays—has raised fears that even legal victories may not prevent long-term reputational and enrollment damage. Experts warn the administration is weaponizing federal power to undermine academic freedom and chill international participation at elite institutions.

title: Trump Administration Scrambles to Rehire Thousands After DOGE Firings Backfire
summary: The Trump administration is quietly reversing course after mass firings orchestrated by the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) left key federal functions impaired. Agencies including the FDA, IRS, Social Security Administration, and National Weather Service have been forced to rehire thousands of previously dismissed employees or reassign remaining staff to fill critical gaps. Some reinstated staff were notified via personal email or phone calls, while others were rehired under new listings. The administration has acknowledged it dismissed workers 'who shouldn’t have been' and is now racing to correct the fallout. The backpedal comes amid a broader unraveling of Elon Musk’s cost-cutting DOGE agenda, with court rulings, public outcry, and operational failures driving chaotic reversals. Services disrupted include drug approvals, nuclear safety, hurricane forecasting, and foreign aid distribution.

title: Trump Crypto Dinner Guest Tied to Chinese Communist Party
summary: He Tianying, a Chinese technology executive and member of a Communist Party advisory group (the CPPCC), was among the top 25 investors in President Trump’s $TRUMP memecoin and received VIP access to a private dinner with Trump and a White House tour. Despite the administration’s rhetoric about banning Chinese nationals tied to the Communist Party—including students at Harvard—He was allowed close proximity to the president after purchasing $3.7 million worth of the coin. He’s attendance, confirmed through transaction records and official sign-in sheets, underscores the administration’s contradictory posture on Chinese influence and the security loopholes in the pay-to-play crypto dinner scheme. Also seated at He’s table were Justin Sun, Cheng Lu, and other foreign crypto investors. Critics warned the event opened the door to foreign influence operations disguised as financial speculation.

title: Supreme Court Allows DOGE Access to Social Security Data
summary: The Supreme Court granted the Trump administration's emergency request to lift a lower court injunction that had barred the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) from accessing sensitive Social Security Administration records. The unsigned order allows DOGE staff to access data including Social Security numbers, citizenship status, medical and disability information, income, and addresses—despite a pending lawsuit arguing this violates the Privacy Act of 1974. Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson dissented, accusing the Court of rushing to support the executive branch without sufficient legal review. The data-sharing initiative, originally blocked by a federal judge in Maryland, has raised alarm about DOGE's overreach and use of personal data for surveillance and cost-cutting purposes. In a separate action the same day, the Court also halted efforts by a watchdog group to obtain internal DOGE records, returning the case for further proceedings.

title: Trump Administration Returns Wrongfully Deported Man to U.S., Files Criminal Charges
summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a Maryland resident wrongfully deported to El Salvador despite a prior court order protecting him, was returned to the U.S. by the Trump administration on June 6. Upon arrival, he was indicted on charges of transporting undocumented migrants—allegations that had not been publicly disclosed before his deportation. Attorney General Pam Bondi claimed the move was consistent with 'American justice,' but civil liberties advocates denounced the action as retaliatory and politically motivated. The case had become a flashpoint over the administration’s mass deportation strategy and disregard for legal protections. Abrego Garcia’s return follows sustained public outcry, a Supreme Court ruling, and media scrutiny of his detention in El Salvador’s CECOT prison. Critics argue that the new charges represent an attempt to justify the government’s unlawful conduct after the fact.

title: Judge Blocks ICE From Arresting Columbia Student Over Pro-Palestinian Speech
summary: U.S. District Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald issued a preliminary injunction preventing ICE from arresting Yunseo Chung, a 21-year-old Columbia University student and U.S. permanent resident, over her participation in pro-Palestinian protests. Chung, who has lived in the U.S. since childhood and was valedictorian of her high school, had her green card reportedly revoked and was surveilled by ICE agents who searched her dorm and visited her parents’ home. The ruling marks a rare legal rebuke of the Trump administration’s attempt to detain and deport student activists, with the court requiring 72-hour notice if any future detention could be interpreted as First Amendment retaliation. Chung’s case is part of a larger pattern of ICE actions against foreign students and scholars accused, without evidence, of Hamas ties—actions that have triggered multiple court interventions and widespread civil liberties concerns.

title: DOGE Official Katie Miller Worked for Government and Private Clients Simultaneously
summary: Katie Miller, a senior Trump administration official and close adviser to Elon Musk during his leadership of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), held overlapping roles as a government employee, political adviser, and private sector consultant. Designated as a 'special government employee,' Miller simultaneously worked for Musk, Trump, and the Republican firm P2 Public Affairs, where she advised clients including Apple and the Consumer Brands Association—some of whom later secured White House access. Her dual roles raised ethical concerns among senior White House officials, who feared conflicts of interest and inappropriate influence. Miller was central to DOGE operations and described by the press secretary as key to its early success. After the Wall Street Journal exposed her overlapping roles, she quietly resigned from P2. The case illustrates DOGE's lack of transparency and the erosion of traditional conflict-of-interest safeguards in the Trump administration.

title: Trump Threatens to Cancel Musk's Federal Contracts Over Political Disloyalty
summary: In the wake of a public feud with Elon Musk, President Trump openly threatened to cancel billions in government contracts held by Musk’s companies—including NASA and Pentagon agreements—because Musk criticized his tax and policy proposals. Trump stated on Truth Social: 'The easiest way to save money in our Budget... is to terminate Elon’s Governmental Subsidies and Contracts.' Critics condemned the statement as a textbook abuse of office. Legal scholars noted the move confirms a pattern of Trump using federal authority to reward loyalty and punish dissent—despite potential consequences for national security and the space program. The White House declined to clarify whether the threat would be acted upon, but Trump doubled down in an NBC interview, saying of Musk: 'If he [donates to Democrats], he'll have to pay the consequences for that.'

title: Abrego Garcia Lawyers Seek Contempt Ruling Against Trump Officials Despite Return
summary: Attorneys for Kilmar Abrego Garcia filed a motion asking a federal judge in Maryland to proceed with contempt sanctions against the Trump administration, accusing it of spending months in 'an elaborate, all-of-government effort to defy court orders.' Although the administration returned Abrego Garcia from El Salvador after a Supreme Court ruling, his legal team contends that the timing of a sudden federal criminal indictment—filed while the Justice Department was under threat of sanctions—constitutes a further act of retaliation and contempt. The filing claims DOJ falsely asserted they could not bring Abrego Garcia back, only to reverse course under legal pressure. The judge had already authorized a sanctions motion, now scheduled. The case follows a broader pattern of judicial defiance in Trump-era deportation policy and echoes a separate contempt threat issued by Judge James Boasberg over a similar deportation violation involving Venezuelan migrants.

title: Social Security Chief Confirms DOGE Embedded in AI Overhaul of SSA
summary: In a Wall Street Journal interview, new Social Security Commissioner Frank Bisignano said Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency remains central to the agency’s modernization plans, even after Musk's departure and court challenges. Bisignano called DOGE engineers a key resource and confirmed that at least eight DOGE staffers are actively deployed to revamp SSA’s systems as part of a 'digital-first' transformation. The program includes expanding AI systems to replace human interactions—handling nearly 44% of phone traffic already—and aims to reduce call wait times, automate benefit claims, and cut agency staffing costs. Bisignano acknowledged internal distrust of DOGE stemming from earlier mass firings and data access controversies, but insisted the initiative will continue. Civil liberties groups warned the overhaul expands AI surveillance capabilities inside one of the nation’s most sensitive federal databases.

title: Trump to Transfer Thousands of Foreign Nationals to Guantánamo Without Notifying Their Governments
summary: The Trump administration is preparing to transfer thousands of undocumented migrants—including citizens of key U.S. allies such as Britain, France, Germany, and Italy—to Guantánamo Bay, according to a Washington Post investigation. Internal documents reveal that DHS plans to begin medical screenings immediately and may move detainees as early as this week. The administration does not intend to inform home governments of the transfers, prompting international legal and diplomatic concerns.
