Trump angrily denied authorship, threatened to sue the paper, and accused the FBI, former Presidents Obama and Biden, and James Comey of fabricating Epstein-related materials. The revelation follows Trump's firing of Epstein prosecutor Maurene Comey and a July 7 DOJ decision to halt further release of Epstein case files—despite prior pledges. Critics accuse the administration of weaponizing state secrecy to bury elite ties to Epstein.

title: Trump Demands 'Pertinent' Epstein Grand Jury Material Be Released After WSJ Letter Story
summary: Following public backlash to the Wall Street Journal’s publication of a 2003 Epstein birthday letter bearing Donald Trump’s name, President Trump directed Attorney General Pam Bondi to petition a court to release 'any and all pertinent Grand Jury testimony.' The move came hours after Trump threatened to sue the Journal, News Corp, and Rupert Murdoch for reporting on the bawdy letter, which was signed inside a nude sketch. Trump denied authorship and denounced the article as 'fake.' Critics accused the president of weaponizing selective transparency: defending a DOJ decision just days earlier to halt broader Epstein file releases, while cherry-picking documents to clear his own name. DOJ previously fired Epstein prosecutor Maurene Comey and suppressed promised records.

title: PCAOB Chair Erica Williams Resigns at SEC Chairman’s Request Amid Trump-Era Rollback
summary: Public Company Accounting Oversight Board Chair Erica Williams submitted her resignation after SEC Chairman Paul Atkins—newly empowered under the Trump administration—requested her departure. The PCAOB, which regulates auditing of public companies, has faced existential threats in Trump’s second term, including a House-passed provision to eliminate the board entirely and fold its functions into the SEC. Although the Senate removed that clause from a broader spending bill, oversight experts see Williams’ ouster as part of a broader effort to weaken audit enforcement. Williams, a Biden-era appointee, had championed tougher fraud-detection rules that were scrapped after Trump’s re-election. In her farewell email, she warned of growing risks to investor protection.

title: Trump Administration Initiates Review to Cancel SpaceX Contracts Amid Musk Feud
summary: After Elon Musk publicly criticized President Trump’s tax-and-spending bill in early June, the White House launched a government-wide review of federal contracts with SpaceX. Officials at the General Services Administration asked NASA, the Defense Department, and other agencies to compile 'scorecards' detailing SpaceX’s contracts, their dollar values, and the feasibility of substituting competitors. Though Trump initially threatened to 'terminate' government business with Musk’s companies, internal analysis concluded most contracts were mission-critical and irreplaceable—especially for NASA and national security. The failed maneuver revealed the administration’s willingness to use federal procurement for retaliation, as well as the government’s strategic dependence on Musk’s infrastructure.

title: White House-Backed AI Megaproject 'Stargate' Falters as OpenAI and SoftBank Clash
summary: Six months after a lavish White House announcement with President Trump, Sam Altman, Masayoshi Son, and Larry Ellison, the $500 billion Stargate AI infrastructure project has yet to finalize a single data center deal. Despite initial pledges to immediately invest $100 billion, internal disagreements between OpenAI and SoftBank over site locations and strategy have delayed progress. While Stargate aims to deliver 10 gigawatts of data capacity by 2029, the project is now targeting a single facility in Ohio by year-end. Meanwhile, Altman has moved ahead with separate $30 billion+ deals with Oracle and CoreWeave, effectively bypassing Stargate. Critics call the launch a political photo-op designed to position Trump at the center of the AI arms race without delivering meaningful infrastructure.

title: Marines Withdrawn from Los Angeles Following Controversial Trump Deployment During Protests
summary: Roughly 700 U.S. Marines were ordered to leave Los Angeles after a month-long deployment triggered by mass protests against immigration-enforcement raids. President Trump had ordered active-duty military forces into the city on June 6—the first such Marine deployment in over 30 years—to suppress protests surrounding ICE activity. California officials sued, and a federal judge ruled the deployment unconstitutional for infringing on state authority. However, an appeals court quickly stayed that ruling, and the matter has not been resolved by the Supreme Court. The Pentagon estimates the deployment cost $134 million. Los Angeles and California officials condemned the action as politically motivated and legally dubious, even as Trump claimed it was necessary to ‘restore order.’

title: FEMA Search and Rescue Chief Resigns, Citing 'Chaos' and Dangerous Bottlenecks Under Trump Policy
summary: Ken Pagurek, head of FEMA's Urban Search and Rescue unit, resigned after expressing alarm over Trump administration policies that delayed federal disaster response during catastrophic Texas flooding on July 4. Pagurek cited systemic chaos and a new rule requiring all FEMA purchases over $100,000 to be personally approved by Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem. Colleagues say the bottleneck slowed FEMA's deployment of rescue teams, contributing to over 120 deaths in the Hill Country region. FEMA officials denied any delays, while Noem’s office dismissed concerns as 'laughable.' Internal documents, however, confirmed a five-day staffing shortfall in FEMA call centers and thousands of unanswered calls. Pagurek's resignation follows that of FEMA's disaster command director and is the latest in a wave of exits under Trump's proposed plan to 'phase out' the agency by November.

title: Bondi Fires Career Prosecutor After Judges Remove Alina Habba From Top New Jersey Role
summary: Attorney General Pam Bondi fired Desiree Grace, a respected career prosecutor appointed by federal judges to lead the New Jersey U.S. attorney’s office after Alina Habba’s interim term expired. Bondi’s move came in direct retaliation for the judiciary’s refusal to extend Habba—President Trump’s longtime private lawyer and political ally—beyond her 120-day acting term. Judges appointed Grace, Habba’s deputy, citing legal procedures, but Bondi called their decision 'rogue' and accused them of threatening the president’s Article II powers. The firing escalates tensions between the Trump Justice Department and the federal judiciary. During her brief tenure, Habba targeted prominent New Jersey Democrats, including the mayor of Newark and the state attorney general, prompting accusations of politically motivated prosecutions.

title: Rubio Opens New Investigation Into Harvard Visa Program, Escalating Trump Crackdown on Higher Ed
summary: The Trump administration launched a new investigation into Harvard University’s participation in the Exchange Visitor Program, ordering the school to produce visa-related records and prepare staff and students for questioning. Secretary of State Marco Rubio initiated the probe without citing specific allegations, saying it was to ensure the visa system 'does not compromise national security.' Harvard denounced the action as retaliatory and a violation of its First Amendment rights, coming just two days after a federal judge criticized the administration’s threats to cut Harvard’s federal funding. This is the latest move in a broader federal campaign targeting the university’s hiring, admissions, and accreditation status. The State Department also confirmed it is screening social media accounts of student visa applicants and considering action against Chinese students despite Trump’s contradictory public welcome.

title: WSJ: Trump Briefed in May That His Name Appears in Epstein Files; DOJ Halted Releases Weeks Later
summary: Attorney General Pam Bondi informed President Trump in May 2025 that his name appeared multiple times in the Epstein files, alongside hundreds of other high-profile figures. According to senior officials, Bondi told Trump the files included unverified hearsay and sensitive material, including child pornography. Trump deferred to DOJ’s recommendation to block further releases. Weeks later, on July 7, the Justice Department formally ended the high-profile review, declaring no client list existed and no new documents warranted disclosure. The internal meeting directly contradicts Trump’s July 15 public denial that Bondi ever told him his name was in the files. The WSJ report has intensified political backlash from Trump’s base, many of whom had demanded transparency. Bondi and FBI Director Kash Patel face growing dissent from senior officials, including Dan Bongino, over the administration’s reversal.

title: Judge Restrains Trump Administration From Re-Deporting Kilmar Abrego Garcia Without Safeguards
summary: U.S. District Judge Paula Xinis ordered that immigration authorities must provide 72 hours’ notice before attempting to deport Kilmar Abrego Garcia again, after he was previously removed to El Salvador in violation of a court order. The judge cited ongoing concerns that the Trump administration might again act without due process or restoration of legal status. The ruling followed Abrego Garcia’s abrupt return to the U.S. in June after being indicted on federal charges, and his lawyers’ fears that ICE would reroute him to another country before he could contest deportation. The DOJ initially held him without bail in Tennessee, but his attorneys requested continued custody to prevent another secret removal. A White House spokeswoman denounced the ruling, claiming the judge had 'grossly overstepped her authority.'

title: Trump Escalates Attacks and Stunts to Distract From Epstein Fallout After WSJ Letter Report
summary: Following public backlash over the DOJ’s Epstein file suppression and a Wall Street Journal report about a birthday letter Trump allegedly sent to Epstein, President Trump launched a coordinated distraction campaign. Between July 12 and July 22, he deployed social media outbursts, revived conspiracy theories about Barack Obama, announced Coke formula negotiations that proved misleading, and posted AI-generated videos. On July 17, he sued the WSJ, while simultaneously calling for release of grand jury testimony—only to privately say it wasn’t needed. On July 22, he openly admitted that his attacks on Obama were meant to shift media attention. The New York Times chronicled the episode as a rare failure of Trump's media-manipulation strategy amid historic pressure from within his own base.

title: Ninth Circuit Rules Trump's Birthright Citizenship Order Unconstitutional
summary: In a major legal rebuke, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that President Trump's executive order seeking to deny birthright citizenship to children of noncitizen parents violates the 14th Amendment. The order, signed on Trump’s first day back in office, had been blocked by multiple district court injunctions, including one from Judge John Coughenour in Washington state. The Ninth Circuit upheld that nationwide injunction, finding that the order contradicts the Constitution’s grant of citizenship to 'all persons born in the United States.' The majority opinion, authored by Clinton appointee Judge Ronald Gould, rejected the Trump administration’s attempt to redefine 'subject to the jurisdiction thereof.' Trump appointee Judge Patrick Bumatay dissented only on standing, not constitutionality. The Supreme Court is likely to weigh in, but the ruling currently blocks implementation nationwide.

title: Columbia and Penn Strike Trump Deals Under Threat of Lost Funding, Pressuring Other Universities to Follow
summary: The Trump administration announced formal agreements with Columbia University and the University of Pennsylvania to end weeks of federal pressure involving threats to withhold research funds over alleged failures to combat antisemitism and enforce federal standards on transgender policy. Under the settlements, Columbia agreed to pay $221 million and impose stricter controls on protests and admissions policy language. Penn committed to aligning its athletics policies with the White House’s stance on transgender participation. The moves were hailed by Trump officials as a 'road map' for other elite universities. Federal officials confirmed that additional schools—including Harvard, Brown, Princeton, Cornell, and Northwestern—remain under scrutiny, and several have resumed negotiations. Critics say the settlements reward politicized enforcement and endanger academic freedom.

title: Immigration Officers Use Stun Gun and Chokehold on U.S. Teen, Say 'You've Got No Rights' in Bodycam Footage
summary: On May 2, 2025, Kenny Laynez-Ambrosio, an 18-year-old U.S. citizen, was violently arrested by Border Patrol agents in North Palm Beach, Florida, after a routine traffic stop involving his mother and two undocumented friends. Laynez-Ambrosio recorded the arrest, which captured agents using a chokehold and stun gun on the other passengers, mocking them afterward, and telling Laynez-Ambrosio, 'You’ve got no rights here. You’re a migo, brother.' One agent was heard referencing a '$30,000 bonus' during post-arrest banter. The video, provided to *The Guardian* by the Guatemalan-Maya Center, shows a disturbing culture of brutality and impunity, amplified by federal enforcement quotas and Florida’s 287(g)-style cooperation agreement with ICE. Laynez-Ambrosio was later charged with obstruction but refused to delete the footage. Civil rights advocates say the charges were retaliatory and highlight systemic abuse in Trump’s deportation regime.

title: Venezuelan Youth Baseball Team Barred From U.S. Tournament After Visa Denials Linked to Trump Travel Restrictions
summary: The Venezuelan baseball team Cacique Mara, which had dominated the Latin America regional qualifiers, was denied entry to the United States to compete in the Senior League World Series due to visa denials stemming from President Trump’s renewed travel restrictions. The teenage athletes and coaches sat for interviews at a U.S. consulate in Mexico on July 14 but were denied. Little League International expressed disappointment and confirmed a Mexican team would replace them. The Trump administration had imposed sweeping travel and visa bans on over a dozen countries, including Venezuela, without exemptions for youth sports. Critics noted that exceptions were made for Olympic athletes, suggesting politicized enforcement. Venezuelan players were left demoralized and without recourse, despite having earned their place on the global stage through merit and skill.

title: Florida Begins Deportation Flights From 'Alligator Alcatraz' Despite Lawsuits Over Due Process and Transparency
summary: Governor Ron DeSantis announced that deportation flights had begun from Florida's new state-run immigration detention center, nicknamed 'Alligator Alcatraz.' Built on a remote Everglades airfield under emergency powers, the facility has already deported at least 100 detainees, with hundreds more transferred to federal hubs. Civil liberties groups have filed suit alleging detainees lack legal access and are being held without due process. Environmental lawsuits are also pending. Despite a $450 million annual operating cost, the state removed contractor transparency documents from public view. Detainees report poor conditions, including infrequent showers and insufficient food, while state officials mock their complaints. The DeSantis administration is seeking to deputize military JAGs as immigration judges, but lacks federal approval. Critics, including some Republicans, warn of spiraling costs and constitutional violations, as the state pushes to double capacity and open a second facility.

title: Trump Administration Interviews Ghislaine Maxwell as Speculation Grows Over Potential Pardon
summary: Justice Department officials interviewed convicted sex trafficker Ghislaine Maxwell for two days in Florida, prompting concerns that the Trump administration may be laying the groundwork for a potential pardon. Maxwell, serving a 20-year sentence, was questioned about approximately 100 people as part of what DOJ described as a 'neutral fact-finding mission.' However, Attorney General Pam Bondi's deputy Todd Blanche, who led the interview, previously declared the Epstein investigation closed, raising doubts about the probe's purpose. Maxwell was granted conditional immunity for truthful cooperation and has appealed her conviction to the Supreme Court. President Trump, a former Epstein associate, denied knowing about the interview when asked in Scotland, but acknowledged he had the power to pardon her, saying, 'I’m allowed to do it.' The possibility of a pardon has drawn outrage from Epstein survivors, congressional Democrats, and legal experts who question the integrity of the process.

title: Federal Judge Throws Out Trump DOJ Lawsuit Challenging Chicago’s Sanctuary Protections
summary: U.S. District Judge Lindsay Jenkins dismissed the Trump Justice Department’s lawsuit targeting Chicago and Illinois over their sanctuary laws, ruling that the federal government lacks authority to override local decisions on cooperation with immigration enforcement. The Trump administration had argued the city’s ordinances hindered ICE operations and filed similar suits against other jurisdictions, including New York, Los Angeles, and multiple cities in New Jersey. The judge ruled that federal immigration law allows for voluntary cooperation, not mandates, and wrote that sanctuary policies 'don’t make ICE’s job more difficult, they just don’t make it easier.' The ruling dealt a blow to the Trump administration’s legal campaign to force Democratic-led cities to assist with mass deportation efforts.

title: Trump Administration Fast-Tracks Deregulation at CFPB, Reverses Military Refund Order
summary: The Trump administration has accelerated its dismantling of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), halting enforcement actions and reversing settled cases. Among the most controversial moves: the CFPB rescinded a prior order requiring Navy Federal Credit Union to refund $80 million to service members and their families for improper overdraft charges. The agency, effectively shuttered by the Department of Government Efficiency in February and placed under the direction of Trump budget director Russell Vought, has dismissed over 20 enforcement cases brought during the Biden administration. Consumer complaints have risen more than 50% in 2025, but the CFPB has ceased meaningful enforcement. Former staff and legal experts warn the rollback undermines financial protections enacted after the 2008 crisis. Despite internal memos prioritizing service members and veterans, the agency reversed course without explanation. Critics say the move amounts to 'backdoor deregulation' and violates the spirit of federal consumer protection laws.

title: Trump Hides Renovation Cost of Gifted Air Force One by Diverting Funds From Nuclear Missile Program
summary: The Trump administration has obscured the cost of renovating a Boeing 747-8 jet donated by Qatar by burying it within a $934 million transfer from the Pentagon’s over-budget nuclear modernization program. The plane, a personal gift to President Trump signed off by Qatar’s defense minister and U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, will be retrofitted with advanced defense and communications systems before being transferred to Trump's presidential library in 2029. Air Force officials confirmed the use of diverted Sentinel missile funds for the project, while declining to release the actual cost, citing classification. The aircraft is being upgraded at a Texas facility associated with covert technology work. Lawmakers from both parties have criticized the lack of transparency, potential emoluments violations, and the undermining of national security budgets for a vanity project. The total cost is believed to be between $400 million and $1 billion.

title: Trump Budget Office Pauses NIH Research Funding in Secret Footnote, Reverses After WSJ Report
summary: The Trump administration attempted to quietly freeze over $15 billion in health research grants administered by the National Institutes of Health (NIH), targeting fields such as cancer, diabetes, and neuroscience. The pause originated in a footnote inserted by Office of Management and Budget Director Russell Vought, which limited NIH spending to salaries and administrative expenses. NIH officials objected, and the Department of Health and Human Services resisted the move. After the *Wall Street Journal* reported the freeze, senior White House officials reversed course within hours. Lawmakers, including Sen. Patty Murray, condemned the freeze as an unconstitutional usurpation of Congress’s power of the purse. The NIH has already come under fire during Trump's second term for terminating grants related to diversity and delaying others that conflict with administration ideology.

title: Federal Appeals Judges Skeptical of Trump's Emergency Tariff Powers in Global Trade Case
summary: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit expressed strong skepticism toward the Trump administration's use of emergency powers under the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose sweeping new tariffs on nearly all imports. At a July 31 hearing, multiple judges questioned whether the law allows the president to override Congress’s carefully negotiated tariff schedule. Trump's 'Liberation Day' regime includes a 10% global baseline tariff, with higher rates (up to 50%) on certain countries. In May, the U.S. Court of International Trade ruled that Trump had exceeded his authority; that decision is now on hold pending appeal. If the Supreme Court upholds that lower court ruling, it could unravel recent trade deals and limit executive authority over taxation. Critics call the maneuver unconstitutional and argue it weaponizes emergency powers for protectionist ends.

title: Trump Fires BLS Commissioner Erika McEntarfer After Weak Jobs Report, Claims Data Were 'Rigged'
summary: President Trump fired Bureau of Labor Statistics Commissioner Erika McEntarfer after the agency released July data showing weak job growth and significant downward revisions to previous months. Trump called the figures 'phony' and claimed—without evidence—that they were politically manipulated. McEntarfer, a Senate-confirmed career civil servant with a bipartisan reputation, was replaced by acting commissioner William Wiatrowski. Economists across the political spectrum condemned the firing as a blow to the credibility of U.S. economic data, warning it could politicize federal statistics. Trump’s aides gave conflicting justifications: some said the firing restored trust, while others accused McEntarfer of incompetence. The BLS is also facing staff attrition and budget cuts under Trump, jeopardizing its ability to collect reliable data for use by the Federal Reserve and the public.

title: Disclosure Reveals MAGA Inc. Operated as Pay-for-Access Pipeline to Trump White House
summary: New campaign finance disclosures show that donors who gave seven- and eight-figure contributions to MAGA Inc. and affiliated groups were rewarded with direct access to President Trump, policy input, and in some cases, pardons and appointments. Donors included crypto executives, oil companies, lobbying clients, and personal contacts. Eric Schiermeyer, a crypto entrepreneur, pitched a federally funded token project at a Mar-a-Lago dinner after giving $1 million. Another donor, Elizabeth Fago, gave $1 million and received a presidential pardon for her son three weeks later. Ambassadorships and advisory roles were awarded to donors who gave large checks—including some with no qualifications. The White House Historical Association was also used to secure access for corporate sponsors. Altogether, MAGA Inc. raised $177 million in the first half of 2025, nearly twice what the Republican National Committee brought in during the same period. Crypto-linked donors accounted for nearly $45 million.

title: Trump Administration Defunds and Shuts Down Corporation for Public Broadcasting
summary: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) announced it will shut down by January 2026 following President Trump's successful campaign to strip its $1.1 billion in federal funding. CPB, created in 1967, served as a key intermediary for funding NPR, PBS, and hundreds of public radio and TV stations across the U.S. Trump justified the cuts by accusing public media of liberal bias. Despite intense public pushback and pleas from local broadcasters, the Republican-controlled Congress zeroed out CPB's appropriations. The move leaves a major infrastructure gap for public media, particularly in rural areas. Most staff will be let go by September 30. NPR and PBS pledged to continue operations but warned of serious financial and logistical disruption. Critics view the shutdown as a politically motivated act of cultural retaliation and a threat to media pluralism.

title: Trump Converts DOJ Into Political Weapon, Ousting Prosecutors and Targeting Enemies
summary: Legal scholars and former federal prosecutors warn that President Trump has transformed the Department of Justice into his personal enforcement arm. Attorney General Pam Bondi has fired dozens of prosecutors, ethics officers, and civil servants—including January 6 case prosecutors, Maureen Comey, and DOJ ethics chief Joseph Tirrell. A new 'weaponization' unit was launched to investigate discredited conspiracy theories involving Barack Obama, James Comey, and John Brennan. Former officials and whistleblowers allege firings were retaliatory, violating civil service protections. DOJ staff report a climate of fear, with firings occurring without cause or explanation. The department has ignored court orders and pursued specious arguments, according to multiple federal judges. Meanwhile, loyalists like Emil Bove have been promoted to lifetime judgeships despite allegations of abuse of power. Legal experts say the DOJ now functions as a spoils system, elevating loyalty to Trump over rule of law.

title: Harvard President Denies $500M Deal With Trump Administration, Vows to Fight in Court
summary: Harvard President Alan Garber told faculty that the university is not considering a $500 million settlement with the Trump administration, disputing a New York Times report that cited unnamed federal sources. Garber insisted no deal was imminent and affirmed that Harvard is seeking resolution through the courts, where it is currently challenging the administration's freeze on federal research funds and a ban on international student enrollment. While Harvard has complied with certain federal demands—such as turning over thousands of employment records—it has resisted others, like divulging student-only staff identities. University officials suspect the $500M figure was leaked by the White House to pressure Harvard into submission, following Columbia’s $221M settlement. Harvard has already eliminated its diversity offices and taken steps to align with Trump administration policy while continuing litigation over academic independence and First Amendment protections.

title: Palantir Surges Under Trump as Legacy Contractors Cut; Consolidates Role Across Federal Agencies
summary: Palantir, co-founded by Trump ally Peter Thiel, has rapidly expanded its footprint across the federal government during Trump’s second term, becoming the de facto core software vendor for dozens of agencies. While firms like Deloitte, Booz Allen, and Accenture have faced over $5 billion in contract cuts, Palantir has received more than $113 million in new awards this year alone and secured exclusive partnerships with those same firms to integrate its software into their remaining work. Palantir is now helping develop an IRS ‘mega API,’ manage ICE’s self-deportation tracking, and unify Social Security Administration and Defense Department data under the Maven AI program. The company’s Foundry software has become a backbone for DOGE-led efforts to centralize control over federal budget data. Experts warn Palantir is evolving into a quasi-monopoly in federal software, enabled by insider loyalty and political favoritism rather than open competition.

title: Trump White House Issues 'Crypto Bible' Advancing Industry Wishlist and Family Financial Interests
summary: The Trump administration released a 160-page crypto policy blueprint described by trade groups as a 'regulatory bible.' The roadmap proposes legislation to legalize stablecoins, restructure crypto oversight, and mandate safe harbors for fintech startups—all ideas long championed by the crypto industry and donors to Trump’s 2024 campaign. The document was authored by a White House working group led by David Sacks, a crypto venture capitalist, and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, whose firm previously banked the world's largest stablecoin issuer. The announcement coincides with ongoing Trump family efforts to launch or expand crypto ventures, including memecoins, a stablecoin, a mining operation, and digital asset funds. Watchdog groups say the blueprint functions as a policy delivery vehicle for those poised to profit directly. Critics warn of an orchestrated dismantling of federal protections in favor of deregulation that could benefit insiders and family-linked ventures.

title: National Guard patrols in Washington begin carrying weapons, escalating Trump's crackdown
summary: The New York Times reports that National Guard troops deployed in Washington, D.C. as part of President Trump’s federal crackdown began carrying weapons on August 24. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth authorized the change, with Guard leadership stating that firearms would be used only as a last resort under established rules of force. More than 2,200 Guard members from D.C. and six states are now deployed, including units from South Carolina, Louisiana, Mississippi, Ohio, Tennessee, and West Virginia. Armed patrols were spotted outside Union Station, where protesters denounced the deployment as a 'manufactured crisis' and an unnecessary escalation. Residents described seeing troops with sidearms for the first time as frightening and a sign of deepening militarization. The Guard’s mission remains vague, officially described as supporting 'community restoration' and assisting D.C. police at transit hubs, though much of the broader federal effort has focused on low-level crimes and detaining undocumented immigrants.

title: ICE uses 'interior separation' to pressure deportations; NYT documents new family separations
summary: The New York Times reports that ICE has begun separating children from parents inside the U.S. when parents refuse to board commercial deportation flights—an approach officials describe as enforcing removal orders but critics call a revival of family separation as leverage. Internal case files show at least nine such separations, including a May 15, 2025 incident involving a Russian asylum-seeking family at JFK. DHS denies any new policy; the ACLU is examining whether the practice violates the 2023 settlement restricting family separations at the border. Related enforcement moves this year also target unaccompanied children and their sponsors.

title: Trump White House readies executive order to punish banks accused of 'debanking' conservatives and crypto firms
summary: The Wall Street Journal obtained a draft executive order directing bank regulators to investigate alleged politically motivated account closures—including against conservative groups and crypto companies—and to consider fines, consent decrees, or referrals to the Attorney General. The draft references a Bank of America account-closure controversy involving a Christian NGO operating in Uganda and criticizes banks’ roles in the Jan. 6 probe. President Trump cited his own account closures in media comments. The draft also tells regulators to end use of reputational-risk screens and instructs the SBA to review banks involved in its loan programs.

title: State Department launches $15,000 visa bond pilot for Malawian and Zambian travelers
summary: The Washington Post reports the State Department will begin a 12-month pilot program on August 20 requiring certain travelers from Malawi and Zambia to post refundable bonds of up to $15,000 to discourage visa overstays. The policy, signed in a cable by Secretary of State Marco Rubio, targets countries with high overstay rates, citing DHS data showing 14% of Malawian and 11% of Zambian visitors overstayed in FY2023. Couples and families could face costs of $10,000–15,000 per adult and $5,000 per child. The Federal Register notice projects about 2,000 travelers affected, with $20M in upfront deposits, refunded if travelers depart on time. The U.S. Travel Association warned the policy could harm competitiveness, while also noting concerns about a separate new $250 visa fee enacted under Trump.

title: Trump alleges JPMorgan and Bank of America refused $1B in Trump Organization deposits
summary: The New York Times reports President Trump claimed in a CNBC interview that JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America rejected over $1 billion in deposits from the Trump Organization after his first term. He said he personally appealed to CEOs Jamie Dimon and Brian Moynihan, but was turned down, describing it as political discrimination. JPMorgan stated it does not close accounts for political reasons, while Bank of America declined to comment. The Trump Organization had earlier sued Capital One after it closed accounts in the wake of Jan. 6. Trump said his company ultimately placed funds across smaller banks. The comments came as his administration prepared a crackdown on so-called 'debanking' practices.

title: Trump threatens federal takeover of Washington after DOGE official assaulted
summary: The New York Times reports that Edward Coristine, a 19-year-old software engineer in the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), was severely beaten in an attempted carjacking near the White House. President Trump posted a photo of Coristine bloodied and declared crime in D.C. 'totally out of control,' threatening to place the capital under federal control unless local authorities acted. He called for prosecuting minors as adults starting at age 14. Elon Musk publicly agreed, backing federalization despite his falling-out with Trump. Coristine, now working at the Social Security Administration after helping dismantle USAID, was with his partner when attacked. Police arrested two 15-year-old suspects. Mayor Muriel Bowser noted that violent crime is at a 30-year low, while the Trump administration has already taken steps to curb D.C.’s autonomy, including a $1.1B budget hit and the creation of a federal 'D.C. Safe and Beautiful' task force.

title: NEH redirects $34.8M in grants toward Trump’s agenda after canceling existing projects
summary: The New York Times reports the National Endowment for the Humanities awarded $34.8 million for 97 projects after canceling nearly all existing grants in April to align with President Trump’s priorities. The largest grant in NEH history, $10 million to the University of Virginia, will accelerate work on the Founders’ papers, with other grants supporting projects on John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, Zachary Taylor, and Millard Fillmore. Acting chair Michael McDonald framed the shift as preparation for a 'grand celebration' of the 250th anniversary of independence. In line with Trump’s executive orders, NEH excluded projects promoting 'extreme ideologies based on race or gender.' While some funding went to Black history projects (e.g., Frederick Douglass papers, Freedmen and Southern Society Project), LGBTQ initiatives were absent and women’s history was minimally represented. The changes follow DOGE involvement at the agency, mass staff terminations, and redirection of funds toward the planned 'National Garden of American Heroes.' Legal challenges are underway: in July 2025, Judge Colleen McMahon issued a preliminary injunction in an Authors Guild lawsuit, ruling that canceling 1,400 previously approved projects likely violated the First Amendment and Administrative Procedure Act. The funds remain frozen pending further litigation, while state humanities councils also pursue lawsuits over lost statutory funding.

title: GAO rules NIH funding delays illegal under Impoundment Control Act
summary: The Wall Street Journal reports the Government Accountability Office found the Trump administration violated the Impoundment Control Act by delaying and canceling billions in NIH research grants in early 2025. Between February and June, NIH assigned $8 billion less in funding than the same period last year, after canceling grant-review meetings and terminating more than 1,800 ongoing projects. NIH also issued cancellation letters targeting projects tied to 'DEI,' 'transgender issues,' and 'vaccine hesitancy,' following executive orders restricting such research. GAO concluded the actions were unlawful, marking the fifth ICA violation it has found this year. The watchdog is investigating 40 additional funding freezes. While NIH/HHS said grant meetings later resumed, officials gave no justification for the earlier pause. The funding gaps stalled vaccine studies, HIV prevention work, and LGBTQ health research, prompting lawsuits by scientists. Senator Patty Murray warned the delays would shutter labs and cut off lifesaving clinical trials.

title: Texas Republicans escalate redistricting fight; Cornyn asks FBI to arrest Democrats who fled state
summary: The Guardian reports that Texas Republicans, backed by President Trump, are pushing a mid-decade redistricting plan expected to give the GOP five additional congressional seats. To block the plan, Texas Democrats fled the state to deny quorum, many sheltering in Illinois under Gov. JB Pritzker’s protection. Senator John Cornyn asked the FBI to help locate and arrest absent Democrats, while Attorney General Ken Paxton sought to have their seats declared vacant and Gov. Greg Abbott petitioned the state supreme court to remove House Democratic chair Gene Wu. Trump endorsed FBI involvement, claiming Republicans were 'entitled' to more seats. Democratic leaders in Illinois and California threatened retaliatory gerrymanders, raising the prospect of a partisan map-drawing arms race. Legal experts warned the standoff could undermine democratic accountability, echoing but exceeding a 2003 Texas quorum break.

title: Migrants vanish into opaque ICE detention system as transfers accelerate
summary: The Wall Street Journal reports that ICE has dramatically increased detainee transfers under Trump’s second term, with 727 domestic flights in July 2025 and a record 58,000 people in custody. Immigrants are often moved across multiple states without notice, leaving families and lawyers unable to track them or defend their cases. Felix Morales Reyna, a Mexican father seeking asylum, was transferred through five states in three months before being deported. Attorneys describe the system as designed to obstruct due process and force self-deportation, while DHS denies ulterior motives. Detainees are frequently moved from lenient jurisdictions to harsher ones in Texas and Louisiana. ICE detention is on pace to have its deadliest year, with 12 deaths since January, and cases like transgender asylum-seeker Andrea Jiminez Tepeque highlight risks of abuse and indefinite detention despite favorable court rulings. Legal challenges argue the policy violates constitutional rights and abuses statutes like the Alien Enemies Act.

title: Trump administration to detain immigrants at Angola, America’s most notorious maximum-security prison
summary: The Wall Street Journal reports that the Trump administration plans to house 450 immigrant detainees at Louisiana’s Angola prison, once known as the bloodiest prison in America. The Louisiana State Penitentiary holds more than 4,000 inmates, 70% serving life sentences for violent crimes. Civil-rights advocates condemned the plan as 'profoundly disturbing,' citing Angola’s history of brutality and abuse. ICE’s budget has tripled under Trump, and DHS is rapidly expanding detention capacity, including new tent facilities and state-run sites like Florida’s 'Alligator Alcatraz' and Indiana’s 'Speedway Slammer.' Louisiana stopped holding juveniles at Angola in 2023 after litigation, but now the facility is being repurposed for adults accused of civil immigration violations. Critics warn the move symbolizes a punitive, theatrical approach to immigration enforcement.

title: Federal judge halts construction at Florida’s ‘Alligator Alcatraz’ detention center
summary: The New York Times reports that Judge Kathleen M. Williams issued a 14-day temporary restraining order stopping construction at Florida’s Everglades immigration detention facility, known as 'Alligator Alcatraz.' Environmental groups argued the state bypassed required federal environmental reviews, citing threats to wetlands and endangered species. Florida is prohibited from adding lighting, paving, or fencing during the pause. The DeSantis administration called the ruling judicial activism and insisted the facility would remain operational, aiming to double capacity to 4,000 detainees by month’s end. The case is one of two federal lawsuits: one over environmental harm, and another over detainees’ due-process rights and access to counsel. The ruling follows Judge Williams’s June contempt finding against Florida AG James Uthmeier in a separate immigration-law dispute.

title: Trump administration threatens takeover of Harvard’s patents under Bayh-Dole Act
summary: The Wall Street Journal reports the Trump administration warned Harvard University it may seize ownership of its 5,800+ patents if an investigation finds noncompliance with the Bayh-Dole Act, which governs federally funded research. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick sent a letter to Harvard President Alan Garber demanding disclosure of all patents derived from federal grants by Sept. 5. Harvard called the move retaliatory and noted its patents include life-saving innovations. The action follows frozen federal research funds, a $2.2B cutoff of new grants, and prior settlements with Columbia and Brown. Experts say such a patent takeover would be unprecedented in Bayh-Dole’s history. The confrontation comes amid broader Trump administration efforts to punish Harvard and other elite universities, citing campus antisemitism and alleged misuse of taxpayer funding.

title: Binance founder Changpeng Zhao mounts pardon campaign tied to Trump family crypto deals
summary: The New York Times reports that Changpeng Zhao, Binance’s billionaire founder convicted in 2023 of money-laundering violations, has launched a sophisticated influence campaign to secure a pardon from President Trump. Zhao hired lobbyists connected to Trump, including BakerHostetler’s Teresa Goody Guillén, who also represents the Trump family’s World Liberty Financial. Binance struck a deal with World Liberty to process a $2B investment, raising concerns about conflicts of interest. The White House confirmed receipt of pardon applications from Zhao and Binance, and advisers have privately discussed clemency. Senator Richard Blumenthal warned such a pardon would reward Binance for financially benefiting Trump’s family. A pardon would allow Binance to re-enter the U.S. market and compete with rivals like Coinbase. Trump has previously granted clemency to crypto entrepreneurs, underscoring critics’ claims that his pardon power has become transactional and entangled with personal enrichment.

title: Air Force rescinds early retirements for transgender service members, stripping benefits
summary: The New York Times reports that the U.S. Air Force has revoked early retirement approvals for at least a dozen transgender men and women with 15-18 years of service. Instead, they must choose between voluntary separation with limited benefits or involuntary removal with almost none, losing lifetime financial, medical, and retirement benefits worth hundreds of thousands of dollars. The decision follows a February Pentagon memo declaring gender dysphoria incompatible with service. Unlike other disqualifying medical conditions, transgender personnel are not being offered medical retirement. Master Sgt. Logan Ireland, a decorated combat veteran, is among those affected. Advocates called the move Orwellian and humiliating, saying it singles out transgender troops for disparate treatment. An estimated 4,000–5,000 transgender personnel serve across the U.S. military.

title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth reposts video suggesting women shouldn'git t vote
summary: The Guardian reports that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth reposted a CNN segment featuring pastors from the Communion of Reformed Evangelical Churches, including Doug Wilson, who argued women should not be allowed to vote or serve in military leadership. Another pastor promoted household-based voting by men. Hegseth captioned the post 'All of Christ for All of Life.' A Pentagon spokesperson confirmed Hegseth’s affiliation with the denomination and his appreciation for Wilson’s teachings. Progressive evangelical group Vote Common Good said it was 'very disturbing' that the defense secretary amplified such views. The repost follows Hegseth’s hosting of Christian prayer services inside the Pentagon and comes amid broader Trump administration moves to promote Christian nationalism, including a White House faith office and a federal task force on 'anti-Christian bias.'

title: Judge rules Trump administration defied order in UCLA grant case
summary: The New York Times reports that Judge Rita F. Lin ordered the National Science Foundation to restore millions in UCLA research grants, ruling that the Trump administration had acted in defiance of a June injunction. The administration attempted to rebrand terminated grants as 'suspensions,' which the court rejected as an unreasonable circumvention. UCLA had lost $324 million in funding earlier this year, including $81 million from NSF, as part of Trump's broader science funding cuts. Letters cited campus diversity, antisemitism, and transgender policies as grounds, mirroring actions against Harvard. Judge Lin said the freezes appeared designed to block research associated with liberal causes. A parallel ruling in Massachusetts found NIH grant cancellations discriminatory against racial and sexual minorities. Judge Lin ordered the administration to report back on compliance within a week.

title: WSJ: Trump family crypto riches tied to Binance-run PancakeSwap
summary: The Wall Street Journal reports that the Trump family's World Liberty Financial has amassed $4.5 billion in wealth since the 2024 election, largely through its stablecoin USD1. The windfall is tied to PancakeSwap, a trading platform secretly built and administered by Binance employees. PancakeSwap incentivized traders with million-dollar rewards to inflate USD1's volume, with over 90% of transactions occurring on the platform. Binance founder Changpeng Zhao, convicted of money-laundering in 2023 and seeking a Trump pardon, arranged a $2 billion USD1 investment that spiked circulation 15-fold. Binance continues to hold those coins, allowing WLF to earn ~$80M annually on backing reserves. Key investors include Hong Kong billionaire Justin Sun and potential partners linked to China's Wanxiang Group. Eric Trump has pursued further deals in Asia, even as the White House wages a trade war with China. Critics say the scheme blends Trump family enrichment, Chinese-linked financing, and Binance's pardon campaign, raising profound conflicts of interest.

title: New Zealand woman and 6-year-old son detained by ICE for three weeks despite valid visa
summary: The Guardian reports that Sarah Shaw, a 33-year-old New Zealand citizen living in Washington state, was detained by ICE along with her six-year-old son after re-entering the U.S. from Canada on July 24. Shaw, who holds a valid employment visa and pending I-360 status for domestic violence survivors, was transported to the Dilley detention center in Texas. Her phone was confiscated, and she and her son have been locked nightly in a shared bedroom, not allowed to wear their own clothes, and isolated as the only English speakers. Advocates argue ICE could have granted humanitarian parole instead. Shaw’s three children all hold approved I-360 visas, raising questions about the legality of her son’s detention. Shaw’s union, the Washington Federation of State Employees, called for her release, warning of lasting trauma. Her case joins a growing list of foreign nationals, including British, German, Canadian, and Australian citizens, detained or deported under Trump’s renewed immigration crackdown.

title: Wall Street banks embrace stablecoins after Trump's GENIUS Act, despite systemic risks
summary: The New York Times reports that Wall Street banks have reversed years of hostility to crypto and are now racing to develop stablecoins, spurred by Trump’s GENIUS Act and the rapid rise of Bitcoin. JPMorgan, Bank of America, and Citi are planning a shared interbank crypto payments system, while also preparing individual stablecoins with loyalty rewards. The Act requires issuers to back coins 1:1 with Treasuries, creating guaranteed bank profits but no interest for consumers and no federal deposit insurance. Critics warn stablecoins could shrink banks’ lending base and destabilize the financial system, echoing failures from the 19th century’s 'wildcat banking' era. The shift also reflects political opportunism, as Trump and his family stand to benefit through World Liberty Financial, their crypto start-up. While some executives privately express unease, banks are publicly touting stablecoins as innovation. The case forms part of a broader pattern of Trump family enrichment at odds with U.S. financial and regulatory interests.

title: Appeals court lets Trump administration withhold billions in foreign aid; says only GAO can sue
summary: The New York Times reports a 2 to 1 D.C. Circuit panel ruled that foreign-aid grantees lack a cause of action under the Impoundment Control Act to challenge President Trump's refusal to spend congressionally appropriated funds, holding that only the Government Accountability Office may bring such suits. The decision lifts a lower-court order that had forced payments to resume and gives the administration leeway to slash aid programs, including nearly $4B in global health funds and over $6B for HIV/AIDS programs. Judge Karen L. Henderson, joined by Judge Gregory G. Katsas, wrote the majority; Judge Florence Y. Pan dissented, warning the ruling green-lights executive overrides of Congress’s power of the purse. The case follows months of freezes imposed since Trump’s first day in office as State Department and USAID funding streams were suspended or terminated; GAO has repeatedly found related impoundments unlawful and has dozens of open probes.

title: ICE documents show plan to double detention capacity to 107,000 beds by 2026
summary: The Washington Post reports that internal ICE planning documents outline how the Trump administration intends to more than double immigrant detention capacity to 107,000 beds by January 2026. The roadmap, last updated July 30, details contracts to open or expand 125 facilities, including mega-centers, tent structures, and at least two new family detention facilities. Congress approved a $45 billion detention budget to fund the expansion, enabling billions in new contracts for private prison giants Geo Group and CoreCivic, each on track to double their annual ICE revenues. Texas’s detention capacity will nearly double to 38,000 beds, while expansion is also planned in states with little prior detention infrastructure, such as Indiana, Minnesota, and North Carolina. The plan includes a 3,500-bed 'Brownsville Family' facility and the reopening of the 5,700-bed Reeves County Detention Center, notorious for poor conditions. Critics warn the rapid expansion risks cruelty, overcrowding, and inadequate care, while supporters tout jobs and local tax revenue. ICE officials defend the plans as necessary to manage record-high arrests under Trump’s renewed immigration crackdown.

title: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent flagged for failing to divest assets, raising conflict concerns
summary: The New York Times reports that the U.S. Office of Government Ethics warned Congress that Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has not fully complied with his divestiture agreement, months after his January 2025 confirmation. Cabinet officials are required to divest assets within 90 days to avoid conflicts, but Bessent still holds farmland valued at up to $25 million in North Dakota, generating as much as $1 million a year in rental income, along with interests in a private equity fund and two private companies. The farmland poses a particular conflict since Bessent is overseeing trade negotiations with China, which buys the majority of North Dakota soybeans. OGE noted that Bessent was required to sell by April 28 but has delayed, citing illiquid markets. Watchdog groups including the Campaign Legal Center and Democracy Defenders Fund filed formal complaints, warning that Bessent may be violating conflict-of-interest laws while directing Trump’s policies on taxes, trade, and financial deregulation. Bessent insists he has divested 96% of required holdings and will sell the rest by Dec. 15, while recusing himself from matters affecting his assets.

title: Trump administration backs off effort to take direct control of D.C. police after lawsuit
summary: The New York Times reports that the Trump administration retreated from its attempt to install a federal official atop the Washington, D.C. Metropolitan Police Department after a lawsuit and an emergency hearing. On Thursday, Attorney General Pam Bondi had issued an order naming DEA head Terrance Cole as 'emergency police commissioner' and declaring a crime emergency under the Home Rule Act. D.C. Attorney General Brian Schwalb sued, calling the order an unlawful 'brazen usurpation' of the city’s authority. At Friday’s hearing, U.S. District Judge Ana C. Reyes sharply questioned DOJ’s sweeping interpretation of presidential powers and signaled she might block the order. Hours later, Justice Department lawyers reissued the directive leaving D.C. officials in control, preserving Chief Pamela Smith in her post. City leaders praised the reversal as a narrow win for home rule but warned that unresolved disputes remain over the scope of federal authority. The clash follows Trump’s deployment of federal forces to cities like Los Angeles earlier in 2025 and marks the most serious challenge yet to D.C.’s limited autonomy under the 1973 Home Rule Act.

title: Judge orders Trump administration to release $95M to National Endowment for Democracy
summary: The New York Times reports that Judge Dabney L. Friedrich blocked the Trump administration from withholding congressionally appropriated funds from the National Endowment for Democracy (NED). The court found that $239 million in funding had been frozen 'for impermissible policy reasons' under the Department of Government Efficiency’s austerity push. The freeze forced layoffs and halted democracy-support programs, including internet freedom tools and support for independent journalism abroad. The ruling ordered the release of $95 million—about 30 percent of NED’s budget—citing irreparable harm to the organization’s global reputation and its very ability to operate. NED, denounced by China and Russia, was one of several democracy and human rights groups targeted by the Trump administration’s cuts after January 2025. Although the administration released some funds after the lawsuit was filed in March, the court emphasized that the suspensions were unlawful and caused lasting damage.

title: Federal judge blocks FTC probe into Media Matters, citing First Amendment retaliation
summary: The Washington Post reports that U.S. District Judge Sparkle L. Sooknanan issued a preliminary injunction halting the Federal Trade Commission’s investigation into Media Matters for America. The judge found that the FTC’s demands for documents were retaliatory and amounted to a 'straightforward First Amendment violation.' Media Matters had sued in June, arguing the probe was political retribution after its reporting on Elon Musk’s platform X, which showed major corporate ads appearing alongside Nazi content. Musk, who later led the Department of Government Efficiency, was central to the administration’s alignment with the investigation. Judge Sooknanan emphasized the danger of government retaliation against constitutionally protected reporting, writing: 'That alarm should ring even louder when the Government retaliates against those engaged in newsgathering and reporting.' The FTC argued its demands were part of a broader antitrust inquiry into advertiser boycotts but lost on the preliminary motion. Media Matters hailed the decision as a critical defense of press freedom against intimidation by the Trump administration.

title: Trump expands National Guard presence in Washington with troops from three Republican-led states
summary: The New York Times reports that the Trump administration is doubling the National Guard’s presence in Washington, D.C., with the governors of West Virginia, South Carolina, and Ohio authorizing deployments of up to 750 additional troops. They will join the 800 Guard members already patrolling the capital under Trump’s executive order to address crime and homelessness, which critics call an abuse of power. The expansion sparked large protests across the city, with demonstrators chanting 'Trump Must Go Now' and 'No ICE! No National Guard!' Local officials warn the deployments threaten D.C.’s limited home rule, echoing earlier clashes over federal control of the city’s police department. National Guard troops have already been used in law enforcement actions, including detaining a man accused of assaulting a Park Police officer on the National Mall. The standoff underscores how Trump’s federalization of D.C. security has become one of the most significant challenges to the city’s autonomy since Congress granted home rule in 1973.

title: Trump fires BLS commissioner after weak jobs data, raising concerns about politicizing economic statistics
summary: Within hours of a disappointing July jobs report and large downward revisions to prior months, President Trump fired Bureau of Labor Statistics Commissioner Erika McEntarfer, accusing her—without evidence—of manipulating jobs numbers. The move drew intense criticism from economists and investors, who warned it undermined confidence in the integrity of U.S. economic data. Ten days later, Trump nominated Heritage Foundation economist E.J. Antoni to replace her.

title: Top economic advisers defend firing of BLS chief, citing data revisions and credibility concerns
summary: White House economic advisers—including U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and NEC Director Kevin Hassett—publicly sided with President Trump in justifying the firing of BLS Commissioner Erika McEntarfer. They cited unusually large downward revisions to jobs data for May and June as evidence of systemic flaws in BLS methodology, reinforcing the administration’s narrative of a need for 'new leadership.'

title: Army rescinds cyber chief Jen Easterly's West Point appointment after far-right activist backlash
summary: Army Secretary Dan Driscoll rescinded the agreement appointing former CISA Director Jen Easterly as a distinguished chair at West Point's Social Sciences department, following pressure from far-right activist Laura Loomer. The move also halted outside group involvement in hiring. The Pentagon later belatedly defended Driscoll, calling him loyal to the administration, though civil-military leaders raised concerns about ideological influence over academic institutions.

title: Texas Democrats protest police monitoring ordered during redistricting standoff
summary: The Associated Press reports that Texas House Democrats staged an overnight protest at the state Capitol after Republican leaders ordered state police to monitor their movements ahead of a vote on new congressional maps backed by President Trump. Rep. Nicole Collier of Fort Worth refused to sign a 'permission slip' allowing DPS troopers to follow her, remaining on the House floor for days while livestreaming the protest. Other Democrats reported plainclothes officers trailing them to their homes and even grocery stores, describing the surveillance as intimidation. House Minority Leader Gene Wu and other Democrats joined Collier in tearing up their slips and sleeping on the House floor in what they called a 'slumber party for democracy.' Republicans said the monitoring was within House rules requiring members to remain present until the scheduled vote. The GOP maps are designed to give Republicans five additional U.S. House seats, part of a broader nationwide redistricting effort driven by Trump. Democrats vow to challenge the maps in court.

title: Trump attacks Smithsonian for 'focusing too much on how bad slavery was,' orders review of museum exhibits
summary: The New York Times reports that President Trump accused the Smithsonian Institution of focusing excessively on the horrors of slavery and not enough on America's 'brightness.' His remarks came as the White House ordered Smithsonian museums to revise exhibits deemed out of step with 'American ideals' within 120 days, threatening their independence. The directive and Trump's comments continue a broader administration campaign to minimize Black history, dismantle diversity and inclusion programs, and reframe the country's past through a nationalist lens. Historians denounced the remarks as an assault on truth and memory, noting that the Smithsonian's National Museum of African American History and Culture already balances slavery and civil rights history with cultural achievements. Critics described the move as an attempt to impose political control over cultural institutions, censor honest teaching of slavery, and inflame white grievance politics.

title: Elon Musk backs off plans for 'America Party,' weighing support for JD Vance instead
summary: The Wall Street Journal reports that Elon Musk has cooled on his pledge to form a new political party, the 'America Party,' which he had announced in July as an alternative to Republicans and Democrats. Musk is now reluctant to alienate powerful Republicans, particularly Vice President JD Vance, widely seen as heir to the MAGA movement. Instead, Musk is considering using his wealth to back Vance in a potential 2028 presidential run. In 2024, Musk’s America PAC spent nearly $300 million to support Trump and Republicans. His team canceled meetings with outside groups specializing in third-party ballot access and has not engaged with backers such as Andrew Yang or Mark Cuban, who had expressed interest. While Musk has not ruled out forming a party in the future, allies describe 'an eerie silence' around the project. The shift is viewed as a relief for Republicans, who feared a spoiler party, and a sign that Musk’s political capital remains closely tied to Trump and his circle.

title: Smartmatic case filings reveal Fox hosts urged Sidney Powell to help Trump overturn election
summary: The Wall Street Journal reports that newly unredacted court documents in Smartmatic's defamation lawsuit against Fox News show prominent hosts Maria Bartiromo and Lou Dobbs privately encouraged Trump lawyer Sidney Powell to continue pushing false election-fraud claims after the 2020 election. On Nov. 17, 2020, Bartiromo texted Powell, 'Sidney we must keep you out there... Please please please overturn this.' On Nov. 7, Dobbs texted Powell, 'It’s up to us – we few!' and vowed to help stop what he described as a 'coup d'etat' against Trump. The filings also include messages from Jeanine Pirro, now a federal prosecutor, declaring her loyalty to Trump and the GOP. The revelations underscore how Fox talent privately coordinated with Trump allies while on-air segments amplified conspiracy theories about Smartmatic, which Fox later admitted were false. Fox maintains that Smartmatic was already struggling as a business and denies responsibility for its losses, while Smartmatic seeks billions in damages. The case follows Fox's $787.5 million Dominion settlement in 2023 and ongoing defamation suits involving other networks.

title: House Republicans plan partial release of Epstein files after DOJ subpoena
summary: The Wall Street Journal reports that the House Oversight Committee, led by Chairman James Comer (R-KY), announced it will release some Jeffrey Epstein-related records it subpoenaed from the Justice Department, beginning Friday. The committee said it would redact identifying details of victims and child sexual abuse material before any public release. Democrats criticized the plan as inadequate and warned that partial releases could be misleading, accusing the Trump administration of continuing a coverup. DOJ officials previously told Trump that his name, along with many other high-profile figures, appeared in Epstein-related files—though without any indication of wrongdoing. The Justice Department has insisted the records include large volumes of sensitive material that cannot be made public. The GOP-led committee has also subpoenaed Epstein associate Ghislaine Maxwell, who is appealing her sex-trafficking conviction, but declined to grant her immunity. Former Attorney General William Barr testified this week that he never saw evidence implicating Trump. The controversy comes amid divisions in the Republican Party over how far to press the Epstein matter.

title: Deportations surge to highest levels under Trump after summer escalation of ICE arrests
summary: The New York Times reports that deportations have surged to nearly 1,500 per day, the highest pace since the Obama administration, after a summer escalation of ICE arrests. At least 180,000 people have been deported since Trump took office in January, and ICE is now on track to exceed 400,000 deportations in the first year—well above the 271,000 removed last year but short of Trump’s one million per year goal. The increase follows a July domestic policy bill that provided ICE with $76 billion in new funding over four years, including money for 10,000 new agents, 80,000 additional detention beds, and more charter and military flights. Unlike Obama’s focus on recent border crossers and criminal cases, Trump’s crackdown has overwhelmingly targeted people without criminal records. In Los Angeles, ICE arrested over 2,000 non-criminal immigrants before a federal court issued a temporary restraining order against racial profiling; similar tactics in New York triggered lawsuits and protests. With 60,000 in custody and 50 new detention centers opened, ICE is straining capacity while facing fierce backlash, protests, and litigation nationwide.

title: Pentagon fires DIA chief after report contradicted Trump on Iran strike damage
summary: The New York Times reports the Pentagon fired Air Force Lt. Gen. Jeffrey Kruse as head of the Defense Intelligence Agency weeks after the agency drafted a preliminary assessment contradicting President Trump’s claim that U.S. strikes had 'obliterated' Iran’s nuclear sites, finding the program was set back only months. It’s the second removal of a top military intelligence leader in Trump’s second term, after NSA chief Gen. Timothy D. Haugh was ousted earlier this year following complaints from a right-wing activist. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth also dismissed Vice Adm. Nancy Lacore (chief of the Navy Reserve) and Rear Adm. Jamie Sands (Naval Special Warfare Command). Senator Mark Warner warned the Kruse firing shows intelligence being treated as a loyalty test. DIA deputy director Christine Bordine will serve as acting director. Tensions predated the Iran assessment: members of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) derided DIA as bloated during a visit and pressed Kruse to abandon the in-house MARS data system for commercial tools.

title: Lawyers say Trump officials threatened to deport Abrego Garcia to Uganda to coerce guilty plea
summary: The New York Times reports that lawyers for Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, an immigrant wrongfully expelled to El Salvador earlier this year and later returned, accused the Trump administration of attempting to coerce him into pleading guilty on smuggling charges by threatening to deport him to Uganda. In a filing in federal court in Nashville, attorneys said prosecutors first offered a deal to deport Abrego Garcia to Costa Rica if he pled guilty, even providing a letter confirming Costa Rica’s willingness to accept him as a refugee. When the defense rejected the offer, DOJ and DHS officials warned that if he did not accept the plea by Monday, ICE would initiate deportation to Uganda. Lawyers called the move a blatant abuse of power designed to force a plea, following months of vindictive actions against Abrego Garcia after courts blocked his earlier removal. DOJ insists he is a 'danger to the community' and can choose to plead guilty or go to trial, but critics said the threat of deportation to a random third country shows the administration weaponizing immigration powers against individual defendants.

title: Trump DOJ fires Jan. 6 prosecutors after mass pardons, reframing rioters as patriots
summary: The New York Times reports that the Justice Department under Attorney General Pam Bondi has fired or demoted more than two dozen federal prosecutors who handled Jan. 6 cases, part of what critics describe as a purge following Trump’s sweeping pardons of nearly 1,600 defendants earlier this year. Career prosecutors like Michael Gordon in Tampa and Greg Rosen, who led the Capitol Siege Section, were dismissed despite outstanding performance reviews. The department dismantled the task force that secured hundreds of convictions for assaults on police and other crimes, replacing leaders with political loyalists such as Ed Martin, a Trump ally who was himself in the crowd outside the Capitol on Jan. 6. Martin immediately dismissed pending cases and demoted senior lawyers, at one point citing Biblical passages in termination emails. Prosecutors say the purge weaponizes DOJ against its own civil servants and redefines Jan. 6 as a 'patriotic' event, while emboldened rioters now sue the government for 'political persecution.' The shakeup extends to FBI agents and staff connected to Trump-related cases, further entrenching political loyalty tests inside the justice system.

title: Muted homecoming for Kilmar Abrego Garcia as Trump officials threaten new deportation
summary: The New York Times reports that Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, wrongfully deported to El Salvador in March and returned in June, rejoined his family in Maryland to a subdued celebration. Videos showed tearful embraces with relatives, but his future remains uncertain: the Trump administration has threatened to deport him to Uganda if he does not plead guilty in a human smuggling case. Prosecutors had earlier dangled Costa Rica as a destination if he accepted a plea deal, which his lawyers denounced as coercive. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem labeled him a 'monster,' echoing Trump officials’ efforts to portray him as MS-13 despite lack of due process. Abrego Garcia remains under ankle monitoring and subject to ICE check-ins. Maryland Senator Chris Van Hollen warned that the administration is using immigration powers as punishment, calling it a constitutional overreach. Local immigrant communities in Prince George's County, already fearful amid National Guard patrols and ICE raids, view the case as emblematic of systemic abuses.

title: Judge halts Uganda deportation after ICE re-arrests Kilmar Abrego García; third-country removal strategy challenged
summary: U.S. District Judge Paula Xinis temporarily barred the administration from removing Kilmar Abrego García after ICE detained him at a required Baltimore check-in just days after a federal court released him pending trial on smuggling charges. Government filings and arguments referenced a potential 'third-country' removal to Uganda even as prosecutors secured assurances from Costa Rica and pursued plea negotiations—raising claims by Abrego's lawyers of coercive use of deportation leverage. Xinis ordered that Abrego not be removed from the continental U.S. until a prompt hearing to ensure due-process compliance and attorney access.

title: Whistleblower: DOGE copied Social Security 'Numident' to vulnerable cloud, overrode 'high risk' warnings
summary: Social Security's chief data officer, Charles Borges, filed a whistle-blower complaint alleging that DOGE personnel copied the Numident file—a master database of all Social Security numbers and associated PII—to a vulnerable internal cloud server controlled by DOGE, without standard independent security monitoring. Internal emails show the acting CISO labeled the plan 'high risk,' but SSA CIO Aram Moghaddassi accepted the risks and a senior official approved the transfer; DOGE engineers John Solly and 19-year-old Edward Coristine were listed as involved. SSA said it is unaware of any compromise and that the data resides in a secure, internet-walled environment; the complaint also notes a March court block later overruled by the Supreme Court on June 6, and alleges gaps in audit/oversight as of late June.

title: All attorneys in DOJ 'Sanctuary Cities Enforcement' working group resign after being sidelined
summary: In the administration's opening months, DOJ reassigned roughly a dozen senior career lawyers to a newly created 'Sanctuary Cities Enforcement' group. Six months later, all had left the department. Attorneys say they were given menial research, told not to coordinate with litigators actually suing cities, and concluded the group functioned as a 'rubber room' to push out experienced staff. Reassignment notices arrived before Attorney General Pam Bondi’s official start, a timing that sources said could avoid a post-confirmation reassignment moratorium. Separately, the Merit Systems Protection Board ordered DOJ to reinstate two fired immigration judges, but members of the working group had little legal recourse because they resigned.

title: FEMA suspends about 30 staff after letter criticizing Trump cuts; retaliation concerns
summary: The Federal Emergency Management Agency placed roughly 30 employees on paid administrative leave after they signed a letter to Congress warning that administration cuts had undermined U.S. disaster readiness. Of 182 signatories, 36 used their names and were notified of immediate leave; advocates called the move retaliatory, while FEMA’s acting press secretary said 'bureaucrats' were objecting to reform. A public employees’ group said the named workers have strong First Amendment claims; others who signed anonymously could face investigation over whether they used government time or equipment. The suspensions came as DHS ordered polygraph tests to track leaks and after EPA similarly put more than 100 staff on leave in July.

title: Trump claims authority to deploy National Guard to Chicago: “the right to do anything I want to do”
summary: In a televised cabinet meeting, President Trump asserted sweeping power to deploy the National Guard in any state, saying he had “the right to do anything I want to do,” while pressing Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker to approve a deployment to Chicago. The report notes his direct control over D.C.’s Guard and a recent Los Angeles deployment under an obscure statute, and adds that Chicago’s violent crime has fallen since 2021. The remarks underscore a maximalist view of presidential authority to send troops into Democratic-led cities.

title: Trump Media sets up $6.4B CRO token vehicle with Crypto.com and Yorkville; deepens crypto ties
summary: Trump Media & Technology Group announced a new venture to buy and hold Crypto.com’s CRO token, partnering with Crypto.com and Yorkville. Disclosures and coverage indicate Crypto.com will buy $50M of TMTG stock while TMTG buys ~$105M of CRO; an affiliate of Yorkville provides a $5B equity line, and Yorkville Acquisition will purchase $1B of CRO and even rebrand its ticker to 'Make CRO Great Again.' The companies also cite ~$420M in cash and warrants available for token purchases. Following the news, CRO rose ~35% to ~$0.21 and DJT/TMTG rose ~6%. Separately, TMTG is raising ~$2.5B for a bitcoin treasury strategy. The move underscores growing entanglements between the president’s family business and the crypto sector.

title: GSA yanks xAI's Grok from planned federal AI rollout after antisemitic outputs; emails show rushed procurement
summary: Internal emails and staff accounts indicate the General Services Administration fast-tracked AI vendors (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Box) for federal use, with xAI's Grok added to purchasing channels via reseller Carahsoft by late June. After Grok posted praise of Adolf Hitler and other antisemitic content in early July, GSA leadership initially continued discussions but, shortly before announcements, instructed staff to remove xAI from the offering. The article also notes OpenAI's $1 first-year ChatGPT Enterprise deal and that neither OpenAI nor Anthropic yet had full FedRAMP authorizations, with carve-outs used for R&D deployments—raising concerns among some federal workers about atypical procurement norms.

title: Fed Governor Lisa Cook sues to block Trump from firing her, testing limits on presidential power over the Fed
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook filed suit in D.C. federal court to stop President Trump from removing her from the Fed’s seven-member Board, arguing the Federal Reserve Act allows removal only “for cause” and that an unsubstantiated mortgage-form allegation does not qualify. The complaint also names Chair Jerome Powell and the Board, seeking to bar them from enforcing the order. A judge set a prompt hearing on Cook’s request for a temporary restraining order; any ruling is likely to be appealed, potentially to the Supreme Court. The case highlights the Fed’s independence and follows intensified White House pressure on monetary policy.

title: White House fires CDC Director Susan Monarez; senior CDC leaders resign amid clash over vaccine policy
summary: The White House said it terminated CDC Director Susan Monarez after less than a month in the role, following clashes with HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. over vaccine guidance. Monarez’s lawyers called the firing legally deficient, arguing only the president can remove her. In parallel, multiple top CDC officials resigned—including Chief Medical Officer Dr. Debra Houry and immunization chief Dr. Demetre Daskalakis—warning against politicized interference in public health after a recent shooting outside CDC headquarters and broader staff turmoil.

title: Trump urges RICO charges against George and Alex Soros; DOJ declines comment
summary: President Trump called for federal racketeering (RICO) charges against Democratic donor George Soros and his son, Alex, alleging—without evidence—that they support violent protests. The Open Society Foundations called the accusations “outrageous and false,” and the Justice Department declined to comment.
