Lawyers said some detainees were legally present under visa-waiver or business-visit programs, while community groups described panic among Georgia’s small Korean population. Critics, including Georgia Democrat Sam Park, called the action politically motivated and harmful to the state’s clean-energy economy. The incident underscored tensions between Trump’s hard-line immigration policies and his administration’s parallel courting of foreign manufacturing investment.

title: Billionaire Crypto Investor Hits Out at Trump Family's World Liberty Financial Firm
summary: The New York Times reported that Justin Sun, the Chinese-born billionaire investor and one of the largest backers of World Liberty Financial, accused the Trump family's crypto firm of freezing $75 million worth of his $WLFI tokens without justification. Sun, who had previously appeared with Eric Trump at a Dubai crypto summit and invested heavily in the company, posted on X that his holdings were 'unreasonably frozen' after analysts speculated he planned to sell them. The freeze occurred as $WLFI began public trading, its price collapsing by about 50 percent in the first week. The incident highlighted growing unease around World Liberty's business practices and its overlap with Trump-era regulatory policymaking. Though Sun later pledged to buy another $20 million in tokens and shares to calm markets, the episode intensified scrutiny of potential conflicts of interest between Trump's official influence over crypto regulation and his family's private enrichment through World Liberty Financial.

title: Pentagon Approves Use of Navy Base for Chicago ICE Operations
summary: The Washington Post reported that the Pentagon authorized Naval Station Great Lakes, outside Chicago, to serve as a staging hub for new Department of Homeland Security immigration operations under President Trump. Defense officials said the base could also host National Guard or active-duty forces if Trump orders a troop surge into the city—similar to deployments in Los Angeles and Washington, D.C., earlier in the year. Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker condemned the move as an illegal militarization of domestic law enforcement and a pretext for sending armed troops into Chicago without state consent. The approval follows a DHS request for ICE and allied federal agents to use the base as part of expanded raids targeting undocumented immigrants. Legal experts warned that any military participation would likely violate the Posse Comitatus Act, which bars the armed forces from engaging in civilian law enforcement. The operation forms part of Trump’s nationwide crackdown on immigration, amid growing controversy over the use of military infrastructure for civilian enforcement and the president’s pressure campaign on Democratic governors to approve troop deployments.

title: D.C. Attorney General Sues Trump, Seeks Halt to National Guard Deployment
summary: The Washington Post reported that D.C. Attorney General Brian Schwalb filed suit against President Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth to block the National Guard’s ongoing deployment in Washington, arguing the president exceeded his authority and was illegally using military forces for law enforcement. Nearly 2,300 Guard troops—including more than 1,300 from seven Republican-led states—have been stationed in the capital since Trump declared a 'crime emergency' on Aug. 11 and assumed control over D.C. police. The lawsuit calls the action an unconstitutional 'military occupation' and a violation of the Posse Comitatus Act, which forbids federal troops from performing domestic policing duties. The move follows a separate ruling by Judge Charles Breyer in California that the administration’s earlier deployment of active-duty troops for immigration raids violated the same law. While the Justice Department argues the D.C. Guard is exempt from these restrictions, legal experts warn that the case could set a historic precedent defining presidential limits on domestic troop use. Mayor Muriel Bowser has condemned the deployment as 'un-American,' while the White House insists it is necessary to protect federal property and assist law enforcement during the capital’s federal takeover.

title: Rep. Ilhan Omar's Net Worth Rises Sharply Amid Questions Over Financial Disclosures
summary: Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-MN) reported assets valued as high as $30 million in her May 2025 financial disclosure, reflecting an approximately 3,500 percent increase from the previous year, according to public records filed with the Clerk of the House of Representatives. The disclosure shows that Omar and her husband, consultant Tim Mynett, hold interests in two private firms: eStCru LLC, a California winery valued between $1 million and $5 million, and Rose Lake Capital LLC, a Washington, D.C.-based venture capital firm valued between $5 million and $25 million—up from less than $1,000 the prior year. Omar's office has not commented beyond earlier statements calling claims of personal wealth 'ridiculous' and 'categorically false.' A Snopes fact-check and other analyses note that congressional disclosures list wide asset ranges and include spousal holdings, meaning Omar's exact net worth is uncertain but plausibly within the reported range. Watchdog outlets have raised potential conflict-of-interest questions over Rose Lake Capital's claims to advise on legislative structuring, while acknowledging that no evidence has emerged of misconduct. The filings were independently verified by the House disclosure database and first highlighted by the Washington Free Beacon, later reported by the New York Post, Deseret News, and others.

title: U.S. Releases Abrego Garcia From Custody and Seeks to Deport Him to Uganda
summary: The Wall Street Journal reported that U.S. immigration officials released Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia from criminal custody in Tennessee while moving to deport him to Uganda—a country where he has no ties—amid ongoing human smuggling charges that his lawyers claim are retaliatory. Abrego Garcia, a Salvadoran immigrant previously deported illegally to El Salvador in violation of a 2019 court order, was ordered returned to the U.S. after his case drew international condemnation. The WSJ article details how the Department of Homeland Security allegedly sought to pressure him to accept a plea deal that would allow resettlement in Costa Rica in exchange for a guilty plea, or face forced removal to Uganda. DHS Secretary Kristi Noem vowed that Abrego Garcia would 'never walk America’s streets again.' U.S. District Judge Paula Xinis has required that the government give 72-hour notice before any transfer, citing safety risks and prior misconduct in his deportation. The episode has fueled accusations that the Trump administration is using deportation threats and extraterritorial removals to coerce plea agreements in politically charged immigration cases.

title: Pentagon Plans Military Deployment in Chicago as Trump Eyes Crackdown
summary: The Washington Post revealed that the Pentagon has been planning a military deployment to Chicago under President Trump's direction as part of a broader crackdown on crime, homelessness, and undocumented immigration. Officials said the plan could involve mobilizing several thousand National Guard members as early as September, with discussions also encompassing the potential use of active-duty troops under Title 10 authority. The deployment would mirror the controversial June operation in Los Angeles, when the Trump administration sent 4,000 National Guard members and 700 active-duty Marines despite state objections, prompting legal challenges under the Posse Comitatus Act. Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker and Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson condemned the prospective operation as an unconstitutional overreach designed to create political chaos. The plan coincides with new White House directives from Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller ordering Immigration and Customs Enforcement to make at least 3,000 arrests per day and expand 'sanctuary city' enforcement. Legal scholars warn the move risks violating prohibitions on domestic military policing and could signal a broader use of federalized force in Democratic-run urban centers.

title: The Trump Family Cashes In on 'the Infinite Money Glitch'
summary: The Wall Street Journal's James Mackintosh analyzed how President Trump and his sons have adapted a controversial corporate strategy known as the 'crypto treasury' model—popularized by Michael Saylor's MicroStrategy—to enrich the Trump family through World Liberty Financial and affiliated ventures. The Trumps' version involves creating a publicly traded 'crypto treasury' company that accumulates the WLFI governance token, which in turn holds limited voting rights in the USD1 stablecoin business. The structure enables Trump-affiliated entities to profit from token appreciation and a 75 percent royalty on WLFI sales, while ordinary investors face high risk and limited ownership rights. The article compares this approach to earlier Trump-linked investment vehicles—including Trump Media & Technology Group, the $TRUMP memecoin, and Trump's NFT trading cards—all of which experienced sharp value declines for late investors. Mackintosh warns that the 'infinite money glitch' strategy relies on exploiting market premiums and political branding rather than real productivity, noting that it 'violates every principle of finance' and primarily benefits insiders. The piece situates the venture within a broader trend of self-dealing and speculative financial engineering in the crypto market.

title: How DOGE Set Up a Shadow X Account for a Government Agency
summary: WIRED reported that affiliates of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) secretly created and operated an unauthorized X (formerly Twitter) account for the Small Business Administration (SBA), bypassing normal agency oversight. According to documents obtained through a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request filed by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW), DOGE staffers Edward Coristine and Donald Park established the handle @DOGE_SBA within two weeks of taking posts at the agency. The account solicited whistleblower complaints via direct messages, duplicating and undermining the SBA's official Office of Inspector General channels. Internal emails showed that the SBA's actual communications staff were unaware of the account's existence until March, weeks after it was launched. FOIA correspondence also confirmed that at least one member of the public submitted a fraud report through the DOGE account instead of the proper oversight office. Experts cited in the report called the move 'a breakdown of legal and ethical boundaries,' warning that DOGE was functioning as an unaccountable parallel structure inside federal agencies. CREW argued that DOGE's actions violated the Federal Records Act and raised major transparency and oversight concerns, as similar shadow accounts appeared to exist at multiple agencies, including the SEC, HUD, and the IRS.
